lead_paragraph: Garbled conversations and dropped calls are the bane of cellphone users  not to mention the dead zones where calls cannot go through to begin with. But some recent products are designed to overcome these annoyances, improve cellular reception, and, in some cases, even extend coverage.

headline.print_headline: Coaxing More Bars Out of That Cellphone

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 — Facing skeptical lawmakers, Mel Karmazin, the architect of a proposed merger of the nation’s two satellite radio companies, announced at a hearing in Congress on Wednesday that the companies would agree to government-imposed price controls and other unspecified measures to gain regulatory approval for the deal.

headline.main: Sirius Chief Talks of Ways to Get XM Deal Approved

abstract: Midsize digital cameras can offer features you generally don’t get with S.L.R.’s, like a movie-capture mode and a “live” back-panel screen, at a price often under $350.
snippet: Midsize digital cameras can offer features you generally don’t get with S.L.R.’s, like a movie-capture mode and a “live” back-panel screen, at a price often under $350.
lead_paragraph: Most people buy their digital cameras in one of two broad categories: compact (tiny, pretty, with snapshot-quality photos) or digital S.L.R. (black, bulky, with magazine-quality photos). Choosing between them is an agonizing task. You’re far more likely to have the compact camera with you when a photo op pops up — and yet in a battle of photo quality, as an Internet commentator once put it, an S.L.R. takes better pictures with its lens cap on.

headline.main: With Cameras, Compromising Can Pay Off
headline.print_headline: With Cameras, Compromising Can Pay Off

abstract: Asia’s stock markets continued to slide today amid concerns that a slowing United States economy could hurt the region’s economies.
snippet: Asia’s stock markets continued to slide today amid concerns that a slowing United States economy could hurt the region’s economies.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, March 1 — Asia’s stock markets closed down today amid concerns that a slowing United States economy could hurt the region’s export-dependent economies, and European shares were off in the afternoon. But there were signs that the rout that began in China Tuesday and swept through global markets was abating, following reassuring comments by the chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve.

headline.main: Asian Markets Decline but Show Signs of Stabilizing

abstract: Federal prosecutors charged an ex-partner of the law firm McGuireWoods with fraud Wednesday, claiming that he illegally obtained and sold shares of various companies for a profit of millions of dollars. The lawyer, Louis W. Zehil, 41, was arrested, and a federal magistrate later set bail at $250,000. Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint against Mr. Zehil in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

abstract: As calm returned to Wall Street on Wednesday, one important concern – that Wall Street’s bet on home loans to people with weak, or subprime, credit is souring quickly as defaults rise and home prices weaken – remained. Wall Street executives and analysts acknowledged that the subprime segment of the mortgage business had faltered because of the performance of loans issued in 2006, but many contend that the problems are well contained and do not yet pose a significant threat to investment banks or the broader global financial system.

abstract: Does Mark Cuban really want the Chicago Cubs “so bad?” Apparently not. abstract: Motorola  said Carl C. Icahn filed documents seeking government permission to acquire $2 billion worth of the telecom’s stock. Motorola said Icahn and his Icahn Partners hedge fund are each asking the government for permission, under what’s known as the Hart-Scott-Rodino securities law, to buy at least $119.7 million and up to $500 million of Motorola shares. Two other funds, Icahn Partners Master Fund and Icahn Partners Master Fund II, are each asking for permission to acquire in excess of $500 million worth, but less than 25 percent of all of Motorola’s outstanding shares.
lead_paragraph: Motorola  said Carl C. Icahn filed documents seeking government permission to acquire $2 billion worth of the telecom’s stock. Two other funds, Icahn Partners Master Fund and Icahn Partners Master Fund II, are each asking for permission to acquire in excess of $500 million worth, but less than 25 percent of all of Motorola’s outstanding shares.

headline.main: Icahn to Buy $2 Billion of Motorola Shares

abstract: Swiss Re said General Electric would divest its stake, worth about 3.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.9 billion), selling half to Swiss Re and placing the other half in the market. abstract: Lunch at the Four Seasons in New York is not so much a meal as it is a performance. The restaurant is typically packed with power brokers and their admirers, assuring that any tete-a-tete gets widely noticed. So it was interesting to see Charles Prince, the chief executive of Citigroup, sharing a table there Wednesday with Sanford Weill, his predecessor at the banking giant.

abstract: Let the bottom-fishing begin. Tuesday’s stock market plunge may have rattled investors, but it also cut the prices of some companies that are widely considered to be in play. One of these, the pharmaceuticals giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, received an upgrade Thursday from analysts at UBS, who wrote that the recent pullback in the company’s shares “reinforces takeout prospects.” Speculation about a takeover of Bristol-Myers has been swirling ever since the drug maker named an interim chief executive last fall.

abstract: There seems to be confusion in the aisles at Marks & Spencer. Stuart Rose, the British clothier’s chief executive, created a buzz Wednesday when he said a combination with supermarket chain J Sainsbury is an “interesting” idea and that “your shareholders would think you were an idiot if you didn’t consider it. Watch this space.” Hours later, the Marks & Spencer board issued a statement confirming that it had considered some kind of deal but adding that it “does not intend to make an offer for Sainsbury at this time.”

abstract: An executive at UBS and a former lawyer at Morgan Stanley were charged with conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday for allegedly passing information about pending stock-rating changes and merger announcements to hedge funds and other accomplices, who then traded on the tips. abstract: The minister of economic and fiscal policy, Hiroko Ota, said there had been little change in price trends in January, after a report showed inflation slowed to zero percent for the first time since May. “Prices continue to be flat,” Ms. Ota said. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, were unchanged from a year earlier, matching the median estimate of economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Household spending climbed 0.6 percent in January, the statistics bureau said, the first increase since December 2005. Economists expected a 0.3 percent drop. The jobless rate was 4 percent, unchanged after the previous month’s figure was revised from 4.1 percent, the agency said.

abstract: Shares of Alcan, the world’s second-biggest aluminum producer, rose the most in two weeks on speculation Brazil’s Compahnia Vale do Rio Doce may make a takeover bid. Alcan and Alcoa, the world’s largest aluminum producer, repeatedly have been the subjects of takeover speculation amid consolidation in the mining industry.

abstract: Apple is sitting on $12 billion in cash, and the pile is growing by more than $1 billion every quarter. How should the high-flying maker of iPods and Macs spend that money? According to BusinessWeek’s Arik Hesseldahl, the company should launch a $1 billion venture-capital fund. Big acquisitions, especially of tech companies, haven’t always fared well, Mr. Hesseldahl writes. Apple also has a tendency to pick up small companies whose projects can easily be integrated with its own.

abstract: Sirtris Pharmaceuticals, whose research into the red-wine extract reservatrol brought the company to rock-star status, said Thursday it hopes to raise up to $60 million in an initial public offering. By going public at so early a stage (the company was founded in 2004), Sirtris is bucking a recent trend in biotech companies, the Boston Globe said. Biotech companies now prefer remaining private or going public through alternate routes like reverse mergers, as I.P.O.’s have proven less lucrative.

abstract: It started in 2001 with two old friends meeting at the Oyster Bar in the basement of Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan, discussing a $25,000 debt. It ended on Thursday with federal authorities saying that they had exposed one of the most far-reaching insider trading schemes on Wall Street in decades, drawing comparisons to the scandals of the 1980’s and involving four investment banks and a web of hedge funds, day traders, lawyers and even a few supervisors, who upon discovering evidence of insider trading, blackmailed the traders to keep quiet about it.

abstract: Few deals have been proposed and rejected as many times as the one between music labels EMI Group and Warner Music Group. The latest installment in the saga came Friday when EMI of Britain said it rejected a proposal from Warner Music, of New York, under which Warner would offer to acquire it for 260 pence per share, or about $4.1 billion. The offer came with too many regulatory risks and was too low anyway, EMI said in a statement on its Web site.

abstract: PAULSON IN ASIA Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., below, will head to Asia this week, stopping in Japan on Monday, South Korea on Tuesday, Beijing on Wednesday and Shanghai on Thursday. The trip will include meetings with the Japanese finance minister and the governor of the Bank of Japan, and discussions about the weakness of the yen. Discussions in China will also include currency issues; Mr. Paulson has urged Chinese officials to move toward a more flexible exchange rate on the yuan. In Shanghai, Mr. Paulson is scheduled to deliver a speech on reform in Chinese financial markets.

abstract: A new book on hedge funds pulls back the curtain slightly on an industry that is gaining increasing attention from lawmakers, regulators and the media. The New York Times says that “Inside the House of Money” by Steven Drobny is less a book of sustained narration or explanation than a notebook of interviews developed from exclusive confabs sponsored by the author’s consulting firm, Drobny Global Advisors. Still, it says, the ruminations of supposedly hush-hush hedge fund operators are richly illuminating and cost much less expensive than the fees they charge.

abstract: Helicos BioSciences, a 71-person firm trying to develop a faster way to analyze genes, is planning to go public in a $100 million stock offering. abstract: You might think that someone who decides where to invest billions of dollars could bend an equity analyst’s ear with no problem. But as Bloomberg News tells it, some mutual fund managers are getting snubbed by stock researchers at investment banks because “securities firms now order analysts to ignore everyone but the customers who pay the biggest fees.” Who are these big-spending customers? Those would be hedge funds, lightly regulated investment pools that use an array of trading strategies to earn profits for their customers.

abstract: Investors and academics have long debated how private-equity-backed companies fare in their initial public offerings. One camp argues that these companies do worse then their conventional peers because they are often loaded up with debt by their financial sponsors, who are eager for a quick exit. The other camp says they perform just as well, or better, than other I.P.O.’s in the aftermarket. Data from Financial News suggest an interesting wrinkle: It may depend on which continent you are on.

abstract: Coming in under the wire, Citadel Investment Group snatched ResMae Mortgage from Credit Suisse, paying about $180 million for the bankrupt subprime mortgage lender. Citadel, the $13.4 billion Chicago-based hedge fund, will pay about $20 million for ResMae’s lending business and 98.5 cents on the dollar for its $160 million loan portfolio. abstract: A380 ARRIVING An A380 airliner with about 500 passengers aboard will arrive at Kennedy International Airport from Frankfurt around noon on March 19 in a test flight to demonstrate what its operator, Lufthansa, and its manufacturer, Airbus, call the A380’s “operational maturity.” It will mark the first time the so-called super-jumbo airliner has been flown overseas with a full passenger load and meal service. Most of the passengers will be Airbus and Lufthansa employees, though some reporters and photographers will also be aboard. Lufthansa has ordered 15 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2009. Meanwhile, another Airbus A380  this one without passengers and operated by a crew from the Australian airline Qantas  is expected to arrive on the same day and at about the same time at Los Angeles International Airport, according to a joint statement by Airbus, the airport, the Los Angeles mayor’s office and Qantas. That flight will depart from Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France, where the A380 program has had unexpected manufacturing delays. Los Angeles International has long lagged in making the extensive renovations to terminal gates and taxiways to accommodate the double-decker airliner, and is still some time away from doing so. The A380 will park on a ramp at Los Angeles for publicity and ground-based tests. Airbus and some airlines with A380 orders have criticized Los Angeles International for falling behind on the renovations. The airport, which is competing with San Francisco as a major Pacific overseas gateway, recently began a $723.5 million modernization of its international terminal that will include at least two gates that can accommodate the A380. Qantas has ordered 20 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2008.

abstract: On Wall Street, markets opened lower but then stabilized.

abstract: Research in Motion said it would restate $250 million in results, far more than it originally predicted, after a review of its stock-option grants.
snippet: Research in Motion said it would restate $250 million in results, far more than it originally predicted, after a review of its stock-option grants.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, March 5 — The chairman of Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry handheld device, resigned on Monday after the company said it would restate about $250 million in results after reviewing its stock option grants. James L. Balsillie will remain as co-chief executive and will join with the other co-chief executive, Mike Lazaridis, to pay 10 million Canadian dollars toward some of the restatement costs.

headline.main: BlackBerry Maker’s Chairman Resigns but Will Remain as Co-C.E.O.

abstract: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the province’s oil sands. The Corridor system transports diluted bitumen, a heavy oil, from the Athabasca oil sands project near Fort McMurray to a processing plant near Edmonton, the partnership said. Inter Pipeline will also assume 485 million Canadian dollars of Corridor debt. Inter Pipeline already operates and holds an 85 percent stake in the Cold Lake pipeline, which transports 330,000 barrels of blended bitumen a day in east-central Alberta. After the Corridor acquisition, the partnership said its lines would carry about half of the production of bitumen from Alberta’s tarlike oil sands.

abstract: The country’s trade deficit narrowed in January as coal and manufacturing exports rose, signaling that growth may pick up in the Asia-Pacific region’s fifth-largest economy. The trade shortfall narrowed to 876 million Australian dollars ($677 million) from 1.38 billion Australian dollars in December, the Bureau of Statistics reported. Exports rose 2 percent and imports dropped 1 percent. Total exports climbed to 18.12 billion Australian dollars in January. Farm exports like meat, sugar, wheat and wool declined 1 percent. Shipments of nonrural goods, which include minerals, increased 3 percent. Total imports fell to 18.99 billion Australian dollars from December. Imports of intermediate goods, which include fuel, decreased 1 percent.

abstract: In what would be its largest takeover in Asia, the banking giant Citigroup bid $10.75 billion for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage that has been struggling with an accounting scandal. The cash offer is part of a broader effort at Citigroup to reengineer its business in Japan, which is the world’s second-largest economy but accounts for a relatively small part of Citi’s business. Citi has suffered some setbacks in Japan in recent years, including the shutdown of its private bank there, which regulators ordered to close in 2004.

Citi has suffered some setbacks in Japan in recent years, including the shutdown of its private bank there, which regulators ordered to close in 2004.

headline.main: Citigroup Bids $10.8 Billion for Japanese Brokerage

abstract: BP said it had agreed to buy Chevron‘s manufacturing company in the Netherlands, Texaco Raffinaderij Pernis, for about $900 million, excluding working capital and hydrocarbon inventory. BP will acquire Chevron’s 31 percent minority shareholding in the Netherlands Refining Company as well as Chevron’s stake in the jointly owned wind farm located at the refinery; shareholdings in the nearby crude oil terminal and storage facility; and a number of associated pipelines.

abstract: NBC Universal has agreed to back a production company started by two former heads of network entertainment programming, Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun. The company signed a deal Monday with NBC’s chief executive, Jeffrey Zucker, at Fresco by Scotto in midtown Manhattan. Under the terms of the deal, NBC will hand over cash, about $6 million, according to Variety, in return for the first crack at programming produced by the new shingle, BermanBraun, which the two executives described to The New York Times as a “ministudio.”

abstract: The Supreme Court rejected Monday an appeal by Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of the telephone company WorldCom, who was convicted of orchestrating an $11 billion accounting fraud that led to the largest bankruptcy ever in the United States. Mr. Ebbers was convicted in 2005 by a federal jury in New York on nine counts of conspiracy, securities fraud and other crimes that led to Enron’s bankruptcy in July 2002. He was sentenced to 25 years in prison.

abstract: Ravelston, the Toronto-based holding company once controlled by the fallen newspaper baron Conrad Black, pleaded guilty Monday to one count of fraud and agreed to pay a $7 million fine. abstract: The financing arm of the Chrysler Group, the American division of DaimlerChrysler, could be sold as its parent company considers options, DaimlerChrysler’s chief executive said Monday. On Feb. 14, DaimlerChrysler said it was keeping all options open regarding the future of the Chrysler Group, leading to speculation about the prospects of a sale or a spinoff. Speaking during the Merrill Lynch Global Automotive Conference in Geneva, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said the same held true for the financing arm.

abstract: A few months after returning from rap-star retirement with a chart-topping album, Jay-Z has scored big on his other line of business: clothing. Jay-Z is selling the rights to the brand Rocawear, the urban-style apparel line he cofounded, for $204 million in cash to the Iconix Brand Group, Iconix said Tuesday. Under the licensing deal, Jay-Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter, will keep his stake in the Rocawear operating company, which manufactures Rocawear’s clothing for men. He will also be in charge of product development, marketing and licensing for Rocawear.
lead_paragraph: A few months after returning from rap-star retirement with a chart-topping album, Jay-Z has scored big on his other line of business: clothing. abstract: The story of Fairfax Financial Holdings “has more twists and turns than ‘The Departed’,” writes Bethany McLean in Fortune. It also seems to have something to inspire every kind of financial conspiracy theorist, whose ranks seem to be growing. Ms. McLean, whose famous article “Is Enron Overpriced?” foreshadowed that company’s dramatic downfall, describes the drama at Fairfax as reaching “from the trading floors of some of the world’s most powerful hedge funds to the offices of the F.B.I. to havens of corporate secrecy like Bermuda, Luxembourg and Hungary.”

It also seems to have something to inspire every kind of financial conspiracy theorist, whose ranks seem to be growing. abstract: Executive perks are getting lots of attention this spring proxy season. Coincidentally, or perhaps not, Gannett, the largest newspaper publisher in the United States, has taken some small steps to limit the extras doled out to its top executives. The changes were noted by Michelle Leder of footnoted.org, who flagged a passage in Gannett’s preliminary proxy statement indicating that “the company will no longer provide its senior executives with any allowance for home security systems or club membership fees.”

abstract: Tribune Company said Tuesday it would sell two Connecticut newspapers to Gannett, the country’s biggest newspaper publisher. The sale of the two papers, The Advocate, based in Norwalk, and the Greenwich Time, carried a price of $73 million, putting Tribune above its previously stated goal to divest $500 million worth of assets.
lead_paragraph: Tribune Company said Tuesday it would sell two Connecticut newspapers to Gannett, the country’s biggest newspaper publisher. abstract: For the two activist hedge funds who had long called for a sale of Topps, Tuesday’s announcement that the baseball card maker would sell itself was hardly cause for celebration. Eisner’s investment firm, and Madison Dearborn Partners, a Chicago-based buyout firm.

abstract: The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said on Tuesday that it would be difficult to break up Chrysler, as analysts and other experts have speculated recently, because of an integrated production system that binds together its various brands. “Chrysler Group is very integrated,” Mr. Zetsche told The New York Times at the Geneva Motor Show. “The technical lines, like platforms, do not go along the same lines as the brands. The less they are aligned with the brands, the more difficult it would be to think of any separation.”

The company, which has now raised $68 million in equity financing, did not disclose terms of the funding or list participants, other than to say the group included eight institutions, private equity funds and angel investors.

abstract: The consortium behind the 11.2 billion Australian dollars ($8.7 billion) buyout proposal for Qantas Airwaysmoved closer to closing the deal Tuesday when the Australian government said it would not oppose the transaction. The government was under immense pressure from unions, politicians and members of the public to veto the takeover under its foreign investment laws, as it had done in 2001 when Royal Dutch Shell bid 10 billion Australian dollars for Woodside Petroleum.

abstract: A group of venture capital firms in the United States, including the investment arm of the Walt Disney Company, was set to announce Wednesday that it had invested $23.5 million in UUSee, a major Chinese site for Web video, The Associated Press reported. abstract: Comerica, a financial services company with assets of $58 billion, said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to Dallas from Detroit, dealing another blow to a city already reeling from the loss of thousands of auto jobs. Comerica said it generated much of its business in the large, fast-growing Southern states. “Moving our corporate headquarters will give us greater proximity to all of our markets, and the additional resources in these markets will lead to accelerated growth,” said the chief executive, Ralph W. Babb Jr.

Babb Jr.

headline.main: Comerica Leaves Detroit for Dallas

abstract: Movie Gallery said Wednesday it would acquire MovieBeam, an on-demand movie service backed by Disney, Intel and Cisco Systems. abstract: Activist and dissident shareholders, particularly hedge funds, are increasing corporate legal work as boards of directors cope with demands from sophisticated investors and proxy contests when those investors seek a board seat, according to The National Law Journal. The report notes that as directors are increasingly confronted by sophisticated activist shareholders with their own legal advisers, they are relying on advice from the company’s outside lawyers.

abstract: Goldman Sachs is expected to bid for the Movie Distribution Income Fund of Canada after the close of a proposed takeover of Alliance Atlantis Communications worth 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion), an analyst said Tuesday. The offer for the trust’s units is likely to be in the $9 to $10 range, the analyst, Andy Nasr of Raymond James, told The Globe and Mail. The income fund owns a 49 percent stake in Canada’s largest movie distributor, Motion Picture Distribution, and Alliance owns the rest.

abstract: Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate magnate who made a fortune by turning around distressed properties, has emerged as a strong contender to buy Tribune, according to a report in The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Zell’s bid for Tribune, which also owns The Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Cubs baseball team, is getting serious consideration because it could buy out the disgruntled Chandler family of California and take the company private, the newspaper said. That scenario is attractive to Tribune management because it would remove the company from the pressure of Wall Street investors.

That scenario is attractive to Tribune management because it would remove the company from the pressure of Wall Street investors.

headline.main: Zell’s Tribune Bid Gains Traction, Report Says

abstract: Telefónicahas abandoned the idea of buying a minority stake in Telecom Italia and forming a strategic alliance, The Financial Times reported Wednesday. Telefónica, which is based in Madrid, said last week that talks with Telecom Italia were “on hold”, but unidentified sources told the Financial Times that Telefónica was dropping the idea of buying a stake or establishing an alliance. Prospects for a future bid have been abandoned for “the foreseeable future,” the sources said.

abstract: We thought it was dead, but the controversy over a widely used database of Wall Street research has popped up again. The debate began last fall when a group of researchers questioned the integrity of Thomson Financial‘s I/B/E/S service, a clearinghouse of analysts’ stock picks. The researchers appeared to backtrack after Thomson disputed their methodology, but last month they published the paper and are standing by its conclusions.

abstract: Are the big investment banks seeing distress signals in Europe? They could be, according to Financial News, which sees a larger trend in Morgan Stanley‘s recent hiring of a top European restructuring banker. The article describes “a renewed scramble by investment banks and hedge funds to hire high-yield and distressed-debt traders” before a downturn in the credit market, which, if it were to happen, is likely to trigger a wave of defaults and bankruptcies. Activity on that front has been low lately.

abstract: Even as a collection of private equity firms are circling the United Kingdom’s largest supermarket chain — and perhaps partly because they are circling it — Britain’s Parliament is preparing to conduct an inquiry into the private equity business. At issue: asset-stripping, “short-termism” and complaints that there is a general lack of accountability for private equity funds, which usually buy public companies in debt-financed deals in hopes of selling them or taking them public later at a profit.

abstract: The largest shareholder in the Nikko Cordial Corporation has rejected a $10.8 billion takeover offer from Citigroup, saying that the price is too low. The shareholder, Harris Associates of Chicago, which manages money for individual and institutional investors, believes that Nikko is worth more than 2,000 yen a share, the chief investment officer, David G. Herro, said. The offer made by Citigroup was for 1,350 yen. The share price of Nikko, which is based in Tokyo, advanced 14 percent before the Citigroup offer was announced on Tuesday and it rose another 1.3 percent yesterday, closing at 1,357 yen a share. Harris owns about 7.5 percent of Nikko.

abstract: A court ordered the YouTube Web site blocked throughout Turkey because of a video deemed insulting to Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey. The largest Internet provider, Turk Telecom, complied with the ban and cut off access to the site. Insulting Ataturk is a criminal offense in Turkey.

abstract: Express Scripts raised its $26.1 billion bid for Caremark Rx, a rival drug-benefit manager, on Wednesday but cautioned that the bid would be delayed by further regulatory scrutiny. In raising its bid, Express Scripts sought to prolong an already tough battle for Caremark, which is twice its size. Both Express Scripts and its competing bidder, CVS, the nation’s largest pharmacy chain, have exchanged barbed remarks to win shareholder support for their offers.

abstract: Inflation fears and volatility are not dampening the expansion plans of stock exchanges in India. abstract: Environmental Defense has hired Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique firm founded by the veteran investment banker Joseph R. Perella, to advise it as the group takes an unusual role in the $38 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU, The New York Times reported. abstract: Some lawmakers are questioning the Justice Department’s recently revised guidelines on combating corporate fraud, asking whether they do enough to protect the confidentiality of legal communications and the right to legal counsel. At a hearing Thursday, two former federal prosecutors and other prominent lawyers are expected to tell the House Judiciary subcommittee and its chairman, Representative Robert C. Scott, Democrat of Virginia, that the new guidelines, known as the McNulty memorandum, are inadequate and do not protect basic legal rights.

abstract: Chrysler is drawing interest from private equity funds, but the United States-based automaker’s substantial losses and its need for capital expenditures would make a traditional leveraged buyout extremely challenging, The Deal suggests. “Chrysler needs radical structural changes, and legacy costs have to be dealt with before it can be an attractive acquisition candidate,” Van Conway of the automotive restructuring firm Conway MacKenzie & Dunleavy said.

abstract: The German energy giant E.On said Wednesday that it might abandon a yearlong effort to take over the utility company Endesa of Spain, or settle for just a slice of the company, now that it faces a battle with two other major shareholders and the Spanish government. The decision by E.On reflects the emergence of a new shareholder, the Italian utility Enel, which seems determined to foil the Germans’ bid. Enel bought about 10 percent of Endesa last week and obtained options to purchase 12 percent more.

Enel bought about 10 percent of Endesa last week and obtained options to purchase 12 percent more.

headline.main: As Hurdles Mount, E.On May End Bid for Endesa

abstract: Greenhill & Company‘s vice chairman, Harvey Miller, who built Weil, Gotshal & Manges into a bankruptcy powerhouse before he left in 2002, is ending his stint in investment banking to return to his roots. abstract: Most hedge funds made money in February but some trend-following strategies and managers focused on the financial-services sector were hit by the sharp market sell-off late last month, Hedge Fund Research, a firm that tracks industry performance, said on Wednesday. Hedge funds returned 0.65 percent on average in February as gains from earlier in the month helped offset the effect of sharp stock market declines on Feb. 27, according to early calculations from the firm. About a quarter of the managers the research group tracks have reported February results.

abstract: Catalina Marketing, which had been on the auction block since December, agreed Thursday to a revised $1.6 billion all-cash offer from ValueAct Capital. abstract: Amid an implosion in the subprime mortgage market, David Einhorn is resigning from the board of New Century Financial. The company made Mr. Einhorn a director last March after Greenlight Capital, a $4.7 billion fund and New Century’s second-largest shareholder, threatened to wage a proxy fight.

abstract: It’s in the media business, but Federated Media Publishing is sending some surprisingly garbled messages. Jacob Weisberger, the chief operating officer of the blog-advertising network, seems to have spoken at length with MergerMarket about what a great acquisition his company would make for some savvy buyer and about how the company is seeking financing. After the contents of MergerMarket’s client-only report made its way to the TechCrunch blog, however, Federated chief John Battelle followed up by saying his company was not for sale and was not in need of fresh capital.
lead_paragraph: It’s in the media business, but Federated Media Publishing is sending some surprisingly garbled messages. After the contents of MergerMarket’s client-only report made its way to the TechCrunch blog, however, Federated chief John Battelle followed up by saying his company was not for sale and was not in need of fresh capital.

headline.main: On the Block? Blog Network Says No

abstract: A tidbit in a regulatory filing late last week revealed that Google paid a whopping 100 times revenues for the video-sharing Web site YouTube. Perhaps more remarkable than the sticker shock, however, was the rhetoric employed by Google’s chief executive, Eric Schmidt, to justify the deal. “If you can build a sustainable eyeball business, you can always find clever ways to monetize it,” Mr. Schmidt told a group of investors Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A tidbit in a regulatory filing late last week revealed that Google paid a whopping 100 times revenues for the video-sharing Web site YouTube. Perhaps more remarkable than the sticker shock, however, was the rhetoric employed by Google’s chief executive, Eric Schmidt, to justify the deal. “If you can build a sustainable eyeball business, you can always find clever ways to monetize it,” Mr. Schmidt told a group of investors Tuesday.

headline.main: Was YouTube Worth It?

abstract: Picture this: A caravan of moving vans and Mercedes streaming out of Greenwich, Conn., is the forlorn occupants sing “Fairfield County” to the tune of “Anatevka” from “Fiddler on the Roof.” That is what came to mind when we read one Connecticut lawmaker’s reaction to a bill in the state legislature that would regulate hedge funds more closely. The legislator suggested it could cause a diaspora of fund managers, all looking for a new land free of oppression. “The hedge fund industry would, by and large, pick up and leave the state,” John McKinney, a Republican and minority leader of the state Senate, told the Greenwich Time.
lead_paragraph: Picture this: A caravan of moving vans and Mercedes streaming out of Greenwich, Conn., is the forlorn occupants sing “Fairfield County” to the tune of “Anatevka” from “Fiddler on the Roof.” That is what came to mind when we read one Connecticut lawmaker’s reaction to a bill in the state legislature that would regulate hedge funds more closely. The legislator suggested it could cause a diaspora of fund managers, all looking for a new land free of oppression. “The hedge fund industry would, by and large, pick up and leave the state,” John McKinney, a Republican and minority leader of the state Senate, told the Greenwich Time.

headline.main: Imagining a Hedge-Less Greenwich

abstract: Less than a day after its rival bidder was dealt a pair of setbacks, CVS raised its offer to buy Caremark Rx, a company that manages drug benefits on behalf of corporations, unions and government agencies. CVS, a drugstore chain, said Thursday afternoon that it would increase the special dividend, payable to shareholders immediately after a merger closes, to $7.50 per share from $6 per share. The latest bid, which CVS called its “best and final” offer, seemed designed to deliver a death blow to a competiting proposal from Express Scripts, another drug-benefits manager.
lead_paragraph: Less than a day after its rival bidder was dealt a pair of setbacks, CVS raised its offer to buy Caremark Rx, a company that manages drug benefits on behalf of corporations, unions and government agencies. The latest bid, which CVS called its “best and final” offer, seemed designed to deliver a death blow to a competiting proposal from Express Scripts, another drug-benefits manager.

headline.main: CVS Raises Payout to Sweeten Caremark Bid

abstract: Microsoft said it had signed its first agreement to license its technology, almost three years after European Union antitrust regulators ordered the software company to share data to increase competition. Microsoft said the deal, with Quest Software of California, was meant to comply with an antitrust order issued in March 2004 that demanded licensing of software that helps desktop computers communicate with servers. But the deal was met with skepticism from adversaries, who questioned how a company with a longstanding relationship with Microsoft could be considered a rival. The European Commission threatened Microsoft last week with fines as high as 3 million euros ($3.9 million) a day for failing to comply with the order.

abstract: The General Electric Company’s Japanese consumer lending unit said it would close 60 percent of its branches and cut 15 percent of its employees as part of a restructuring plan. The GE Consumer Finance Company, a Tokyo-based lender, will shut 73 of its 115 branches and 200 of its 1,342 unmanned outlets, the firm said. The company said it would also cut as many as 400 employees out of 2,600 by the end of June.

The company’s audacious $27 billion acquisition of Guidant in a bidding war with Johnson & Johnson was viewed on Wall Street as too expensive at best. abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken a step toward combating stock spam, the unsolicited bulk e-mail message that promotes cheap stocks for quick profits, which usually prove illusory. Starting an enforcement effort that (no doubt in a Monty-Python-esque moment of inspiration) it has named Operation Spamalot, the S.E.C. suspended trading in 35 stocks that had been promoted in recent spam campaigns. The suspensions will last for 10 days. The S.E.C. said that further investigation could lead to arrests.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken a step toward combating stock spam, the unsolicited bulk e-mail message that promotes cheap stocks for quick profits, which usually prove illusory. Starting an enforcement effort that (no doubt in a Monty-Python-esque moment of inspiration) it has named Operation Spamalot, the S.E.C. suspended trading in 35 stocks that had been promoted in recent spam campaigns. The suspensions will last for 10 days. The S.E.C. said that further investigation could lead to arrests.

headline.main: S.E.C. Begins Operation Spamalot

abstract: New Century Financial, the troubled mortgage company, said Thursday that it had stopped accepting new loan applications as it tried to negotiate terms with banks that had cut off its access to billions of dollars in funds. But in an indication that at least one of its lenders continues to have confidence in the company, New Century said it had received $265 million to finance loans and cover other obligations and $710 million to replace a credit line. The company did not identify the lender, but The New York Times reported that it was Morgan Stanley who provided the loan.

But in an indication that at least one of its lenders continues to have confidence in the company, New Century said it had received $265 million to finance loans and cover other obligations and $710 million to replace a credit line. The company did not identify the lender, but The New York Times reported that it was Morgan Stanley who provided the loan.

headline.main: Banks Cut Off New Century’s Credit

abstract: At least one investment bank plans on storing nuts ahead of a possible economic winter. After the announcement yesterday that Greenhill & Company lost its vice chairman, Harvey R. Miller, to his old law firm, the boutique investment bank is apparently planning to ramp up its restructuring advisory arm. Mr. Miller, the most prominent bankruptcy lawyer in the nation, has left the investment bank, where he performed advisory work, to return to Weil, Gotshal & Manges‘ restructuring practice.

headline.main: Top Bankruptcy Lawyer Leaves Greenhill

abstract: A real estate promoter was charged in a federal indictment unsealed Thursday with stealing tens of millions of dollars from investors in a Ponzi scheme and using the money to pay for jewelry, luxury automobiles, and credit card and tax bills. The promoter, Gene A. O’Neal, 36, of Atlanta, entered a not guilty plea at a hearing in federal court in Atlanta, said Patrick Crosby, a spokesman for the United States attorney’s office. Bond was set at $50,000, but O’Neal was expected to post that and be released, Mr. Crosby said.
lead_paragraph: A real estate promoter was charged in a federal indictment unsealed Thursday with stealing tens of millions of dollars from investors in a Ponzi scheme and using the money to pay for jewelry, luxury automobiles, and credit card and tax bills. The promoter, Gene A. O’Neal, 36, of Atlanta, entered a not guilty plea at a hearing in federal court in Atlanta, said Patrick Crosby, a spokesman for the United States attorney’s office. Bond was set at $50,000, but O’Neal was expected to post that and be released, Mr. Crosby said.

headline.main: Real Estate Promoter Is Indicted in Ponzi Scheme

abstract: Two former executives at the computer maker Gateway were found liable on civil claims that they manipulated financial results to meet Wall Street expectations in 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday. The verdicts against Gateway’s former chief financial officer, John J. Todd, and the former controller, Robert D. Manza, were announced by a federal jury in San Diego after a three-week trial, the S.E.C. said.
lead_paragraph: Two former executives at the computer maker Gateway were found liable on civil claims that they manipulated financial results to meet Wall Street expectations in 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday. The verdicts against Gateway’s former chief financial officer, John J. Todd, and the former controller, Robert D. Manza, were announced by a federal jury in San Diego after a three-week trial, the S.E.C. said.

headline.main: Ex-Gateway Officers Found Liable in Trial

abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is asking tax lawyers and accountants who create tax shelters and exploit loopholes to take the lead in writing some of its new tax rules. The pilot project represents a further expansion of the increasingly common federal government practice of asking outsiders to do more of its work, prompting academics and other critics to complain that the government is going too far. They worry that having private lawyers and accountants draft tax rules could allow them to subtly skew them in favor of their clients.

The pilot project represents a further expansion of the increasingly common federal government practice of asking outsiders to do more of its work, prompting academics and other critics to complain that the government is going too far. They worry that having private lawyers and accountants draft tax rules could allow them to subtly skew them in favor of their clients.

headline.main: Have Foxes Gotten into the I.R.S.’ Henhouse?

abstract: The latest hedge fund to hit the public markets found the reception not quite as warm as it had hoped. Brevan Howard Asset Management raised 770 million euros ($1 billion) in an initial public offering of hedge fund BH Macro Limited, about half of the maximum amount originally sought. London-based Brevan Howard had said it planned to raise as much as 1.5 billion euros. The middling performance may be due, in part, to investor wariness after the stock-market swings during the past two weeks and declines in the shares of rivals.

abstract: Manulife Securities International is proceeding with a class-action lawsuit against France’s Société Générale for its role in the collapse of Canadian hedge fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. Portus collapsed in 2005 after the Ontario Securities Commission began a probe of questionable transactions. Shortly after, Manulife took over claims of 6,600 of its clients who had invested 245 million dollars in Portus.

abstract: Japanese electronics conglomerate NEC, dogged by accounting troubles, said its shares may be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market because it would likely miss a deadline for filing an earnings report. NEC, which unsettled investors by restating earnings three times last year, said it was still recalculating figures for the past business year and would probably fail to file the report by April 2, a deadline that has been twice extended by Nasdaq.
lead_paragraph: Japanese electronics conglomerate NEC, dogged by accounting troubles, said its shares may be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market because it would likely miss a deadline for filing an earnings report. NEC, which unsettled investors by restating earnings three times last year, said it was still recalculating figures for the past business year and would probably fail to file the report by April 2, a deadline that has been twice extended by Nasdaq.

headline.main: Nasdaq May Give NEC the Boot

abstract: Drinker Biddle & Reath reported a 10.3 percent increase in gross revenue for 2006, following its merger with rival law firm Gardner Carton & Douglas. Calling it a “substantial growth year”, the firm said revenue rose from $223 million in 2005 to $246 million in 2006. That number includes one month’s revenue from Gardner Carton, because Drinker Biddle’s fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 2007, and the merger was consummated on Jan. 1.

abstract: Lawmakers clashed Thursday over the idea of giving shareholders a voice in approving executive pay, while a top regulator scolded companies for failing to deliver the clear-cut pay disclosures now expected by the Securities and Exchange Commission. After a House hearing, Rep. Barney Frank (D-Mass.), chairman of the Financial Services Committee, said his panel would vote this month on a bill that would require all companies to allow shareholders to vote annually on pay deals approved by directors, as well as on “golden parachutes” for departing executives.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers clashed Thursday over the idea of giving shareholders a voice in approving executive pay, while a top regulator scolded companies for failing to deliver the clear-cut pay disclosures now expected by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Barney Frank (D-Mass.), chairman of the Financial Services Committee, said his panel would vote this month on a bill that would require all companies to allow shareholders to vote annually on pay deals approved by directors, as well as on “golden parachutes” for departing executives.

headline.main: Sparks Fly at Congressional Hearing on Executive Pay

abstract: Shares of Clearwire, a wireless Internet service provider founded by cellular phone pioneer Craig McCaw, fell in their first day of trading Thursday after the company raised $600 million in an initial public stock offering. The company sold 24 million shares priced at $25 each on Wednesday night. The stock was priced at the upper end of its expected range of $23 to $25 and the total number of shares was increased from 20 million at the last moment.

abstract: Citigroup and Morgan Stanley agreed to invest in the National Stock Exchange of India, the nation’s largest, after volumes doubled in four years. Morgan Stanley will take a 3 percent stake, Citigroup will take 2 percent and Actis Capital will buy 1 percent, the exchange said in a statement. The NYSE Group and Goldman Sachs in January bought 5 percent stakes in a transaction that valued the Mumbai-based bourse at $2.3 billion.

abstract: Wireless messaging and entertainment software developer Gemini Mobile Technologies has received $20 million in new funding, intended to support continued global expansion and product development. The internationally focused company, which splits its operations among the U.S., Japan and China, added Goldman Sachs of New York to its roster of investors in the new round. Follow-on funding came from three Japanese backers: Mitsubishi-UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Bank and Tokyo Marine.

abstract: Senior management at ferry operator Irish Continental Group have made a board-backed 471 million euro ($619 million) buyout offer, the company said Thursday. But with shares trading higher than the offer price, investors might be holding out for better terms, The Deal noted. The buyout proposes paying Irish Continental stockholders 18.50 euros per share, which would represent an 18.6 percent premium to the closing share price on Wednesday, the last day before an approach was announced. Irish Continental shareholders will have the option of cash or a redeemable preference share alternative.

abstract: How hedge fund money is changing the financial landscape — not to mention that of art, fashion and cinema — is oft-told tale of late. abstract: Applebee’s International said that the activist hedge fund run by a former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman that has hounded it for months has rejected an offer of two board seats. Breeden Capital Management, run by Richard Breeden, declined an offer of one seat on March 2 and a second on Thursday, the casual-dining chain said in a statement Friday. The hedge fund, which is Applebee’s third-largest shareholder with a 5.3 percent stake, proposed a slate of four directors, including a former United States ambassador to Britain after criticizing the chain for failing to improve its performance.

abstract: Vice presidents are apparently getting a lot of attention on Wall Street — and we aren’t talking about Dick Cheney. Heidi Moore of Financial News reports that many investment banks are looking to hire people at the vice-president level but are finding them to be in short supply. Hedge funds (which seem to get the blame for almost anything these days) are pegged as one cause of the shortage: Ms. Moore reports that they are dangling compensation of up to $1 million to bankers just two or three years out of school.

abstract: Hedge fund managers are known for making well-timed trades. The managers at Fortress Investment Group, the first United States hedge fund firm to go public, seem to have a knack for well-timed I.P.O.’s as well. Fortress held its initial public offering the morning on February 9 — which just happens to have been the cutoff date for inclusion in Forbes’ annual list of the world’s billionaires. As a result, five Fortress executives have made the latest list, which Forbes rolled out on Friday, with just a few hours to spare.

abstract: A flurry of articles raising questions about Google‘s $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube — a flurry that included an item on DealBook — totally misses the point. That is the view of Henry Blodget, the author and former Internet analyst, who wrote about this recent negativity on his Internet Outsider blog. Last week’s revelation that YouTube booked just $15 million in revenue last year, meaning that Google paid more than 100 times revenue for the video-sharing Web site, is basically “irrelevant,” Mr. Blodget wrote.

abstract: When I was a little girl in the 1960s, living in Rochester, my mother had her own ideas about music that children might like.
snippet: When I was a little girl in the 1960s, living in Rochester, my mother had her own ideas about music that children might like.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a little girl in the 1960s, living in Rochester, my mother had her own ideas about music that children might like. In a nod to conventional parenting, she played the obligatory Burl Ives record or two. But most of the music heard in our house was what she enjoyed listening to, including Eartha Kitt's swarthy "Just an Old Fashioned Girl" and Miriam Makeba's scandalously irreverent "One More Dance."

headline.main: Analog Memories in a Digital World
History 2.0

abstract: Get ready: The chill that private equity funds have been feeling in Europe may be about to cross the pond. Lawmakers in the United States are considering taxing the rich fees that private equity bigwigs earn as income, rather than the capital gains that they are currently considered to be. Such a move would take a big chunk out of the 20 percent performance fees that private equity firms charge and will no doubt be fought tooth and nail by the industry.

abstract: Adaptive Planning, a provider of collaborative business performance management (BPM) software, announced Friday that it had completed a $7.5 million round of financing. Cardinal Venture Capital led the round, which also included participation from previous investors ONSET Ventures and Monitor Ventures.
lead_paragraph: Adaptive Planning, a provider of collaborative business performance management (BPM) software, announced Friday that it had completed a $7.5 million round of financing. Cardinal Venture Capital led the round, which also included participation from previous investors ONSET Ventures and Monitor Ventures.

headline.main: Adaptive Planning Taps V.C. Funding

abstract: Shareholders of Hutchison Telecommunications International have approved the $11.1 billion sale of its Indian unit to Vodafone Group, a transaction that will finance a special dividend and expansion in Southeast Asia. Stockholders representing a majority of Hutchison Telecom’s shares approved the sale at an extraordinary general meeting in Hong Kong, Tim Pennington, chief financial officer of Hutchison, said Friday. The plan got “overwhelming support,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders of Hutchison Telecommunications International have approved the $11.1 billion sale of its Indian unit to Vodafone Group, a transaction that will finance a special dividend and expansion in Southeast Asia. Stockholders representing a majority of Hutchison Telecom’s shares approved the sale at an extraordinary general meeting in Hong Kong, Tim Pennington, chief financial officer of Hutchison, said Friday. The plan got “overwhelming support,” he said.

headline.main: Hutchinson Shareholders OK Vodafone Deal

abstract: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former human resources director, accused of conspiring with the company’s former chief executive to manipulate stock option grants, asked a judge for a separate trial. Stephanie Jensen, charged in August with conspiracy, fraud and false securities filing, seeks to sever her case from that of Brocade’s former C.E.O., Greg Reyes, so he can provide exculpatory testimony at her trial, according to a filing in San Francisco federal court Friday.
lead_paragraph: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former human resources director, accused of conspiring with the company’s former chief executive to manipulate stock option grants, asked a judge for a separate trial. Stephanie Jensen, charged in August with conspiracy, fraud and false securities filing, seeks to sever her case from that of Brocade’s former C.E.O., Greg Reyes, so he can provide exculpatory testimony at her trial, according to a filing in San Francisco federal court Friday.

headline.main: Former Brocade Official Seeks a Separate Trial

abstract: Amid the increasingly heated debate over executive pay, The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson takes a look at how illuminating the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires in companies’ pay filings really are. Calling the filings an exercise in exhaustion, Ms. Morgenson suggests that the additional data now required by the S.E.C. — with a view to helping shareholders better understand the details of executive compensation — has produced opaque results.
lead_paragraph: Amid the increasingly heated debate over executive pay, The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson takes a look at how illuminating the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires in companies’ pay filings really are. Calling the filings an exercise in exhaustion, Ms. Morgenson suggests that the additional data now required by the S.E.C. — with a view to helping shareholders better understand the details of executive compensation — has produced opaque results.

headline.main: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports

abstract: Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCoopers’s own tax filings. Russian officials have compared the Yukos affair to the Enron scandal in the United States, with ominous implications for the firm.
lead_paragraph: Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCoopers’s own tax filings. Russian officials have compared the Yukos affair to the Enron scandal in the United States, with ominous implications for the firm.

headline.main: Russian Prosecutors Search Office of Yukos’s Audit Firm

abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britain’s largest drugstore chain. The move comes amid a flurry of buyout interest in European retailers. K.K.R., based in New York, and Mr. Pessina, who is the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots and its largest shareholder, made a friendly approach worth 1,000 pence in cash for each Alliance share, or about 9.7 billion pounds ($19 billion).
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britain’s largest drugstore chain. The move comes amid a flurry of buyout interest in European retailers. K.K.R., based in New York, and Mr. Pessina, who is the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots and its largest shareholder, made a friendly approach worth 1,000 pence in cash for each Alliance share, or about 9.7 billion pounds ($19 billion).

headline.main: Buyout Firm and Partner Bid for British Drugstores

abstract: China will create an agency to invest its immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the country’s finance minister announced on Friday. The minister, Jin Renqing, offered no specifics about how much of China’s currency reserves would be under the agency’s control. But whatever the precise figure, analysts say that the agency is certain to begin life as one of the world’s biggest investment funds.
lead_paragraph: China will create an agency to invest its immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the country’s finance minister announced on Friday. The minister, Jin Renqing, offered no specifics about how much of China’s currency reserves would be under the agency’s control. But whatever the precise figure, analysts say that the agency is certain to begin life as one of the world’s biggest investment funds.

headline.main: China to Launch Mammoth Investment Fund

abstract: Warren E. Buffett, dubbed the Oracle of Omaha for his savvy investments in publicly-traded companies, may be facing some competition from buyout shops. BusinessWeek notes that private equity firms, with their coffers bulging with unprecedented amounts of cash, are taking minority stakes in public companies. And, the magazine says, their involvement is causing the halo effect usually reserved for the likes of Mr. Buffett, signaling that there may be a new player to mimic in the market.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett, dubbed the Oracle of Omaha for his savvy investments in publicly-traded companies, may be facing some competition from buyout shops. BusinessWeek notes that private equity firms, with their coffers bulging with unprecedented amounts of cash, are taking minority stakes in public companies. And, the magazine says, their involvement is causing the halo effect usually reserved for the likes of Mr. Buffett, signaling that there may be a new player to mimic in the market.

headline.main: Is Private Equity the Next Oracle of Omaha?

abstract: Strategic Hotels & Resorts, a chain of luxury accommodations, may be the latest real estate investment trust to be the target of a buyout bid. Those who are reportedly mulling a move on the Chicago-based REIT include the Blackstone Group, the Carlyle Group and Walton Street Capital.
lead_paragraph: Strategic Hotels & Resorts, a chain of luxury accommodations, may be the latest real estate investment trust to be the target of a buyout bid. Those who are reportedly mulling a move on the Chicago-based REIT include the Blackstone Group, the Carlyle Group and Walton Street Capital.

headline.main: Private Equity Said to Be Circling Strategic Hotels

abstract: A 76-year-old Montreal lawyer with a penchant for preserving Scottish culture has emerged as an alleged culprit in the collapse of Canadian hedge-fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. KPMG, the court-appointed receiver overseeing Portus, has filed a lawsuit against the lawyer, Anthony Malcolm, alleging that he set up a series of offshore accounts that Portus co-founder Boaz Manor used to siphon off $17.6 million of client money.
lead_paragraph: A 76-year-old Montreal lawyer with a penchant for preserving Scottish culture has emerged as an alleged culprit in the collapse of Canadian hedge-fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. KPMG, the court-appointed receiver overseeing Portus, has filed a lawsuit against the lawyer, Anthony Malcolm, alleging that he set up a series of offshore accounts that Portus co-founder Boaz Manor used to siphon off $17.6 million of client money.

headline.main: Canadian Lawyer Sued Over Hedge Fund Collapse

abstract: Safestore, Britain’s largest self-storage operator, has raised more than 150 million pounds ($291 million) for its private-equity owners in an initial public offering that comes a year after debt refinancing gave shareholders a 100 million pounds payout. The company said on Friday that it raised 209 million pounds from floating almost half of the firm on the London market, putting a value on the business of 449 million pounds.
lead_paragraph: Safestore, Britain’s largest self-storage operator, has raised more than 150 million pounds ($291 million) for its private-equity owners in an initial public offering that comes a year after debt refinancing gave shareholders a 100 million pounds payout. The company said on Friday that it raised 209 million pounds from floating almost half of the firm on the London market, putting a value on the business of 449 million pounds.

headline.main: Private-Equity Backer Floats British Self-Storage Firm

abstract: Goldman Sachs is relocating investment banker John Waldron from New York to London, where he will be co-head of the group that advises private equity firms. Reuters said the move is “another signal of the sector’s growing significance in Europe.”
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is relocating investment banker John Waldron from New York to London, where he will be co-head of the group that advises private equity firms. Reuters said the move is “another signal of the sector’s growing significance in Europe.”

headline.main: Goldman Sends Buyout Banker to London

abstract: Ford Motor is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies in a deal that will be announced Monday, according to The New York Times. The Times said that Ford, which put Aston Martin up for sale last August, will retain a 15 percent stake in the marque.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies in a deal that will be announced Monday, according to The New York Times. The Times said that Ford, which put Aston Martin up for sale last August, will retain a 15 percent stake in the marque.

headline.main: Ford Closes in on Aston Martin Deal

abstract: CVC Capital, a European private equity firm with $24 billion in assets under management, said Monday that it hired Robert L. Berner III as a partner to help expand its business in the United States. Mr. Berner, formerly a managing director at Ripplewood Holdings, will be a partner in CVC’s recently opened New York office, CVC said.
lead_paragraph: CVC Capital, a European private equity firm with $24 billion in assets under management, said Monday that it hired Robert L. Berner III as a partner to help expand its business in the United States. Mr. Berner, formerly a managing director at Ripplewood Holdings, will be a partner in CVC’s recently opened New York office, CVC said.

headline.main: CVC Capital Adds Partner in New York

abstract: Arguing that the competitiveness of the United States’ capital markets is “under strain,” a committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce on Monday proposed a series of steps to ease the regulatory burdens for U.S. companies. The report, which noted a “substantial decrease” in the number of initial public offerings in the U.S., called for the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to be folded into the 1934 law that created the Securities and Exchange Commission and urged companies to stop giving quarterly earnings guidance.
lead_paragraph: Arguing that the competitiveness of the United States’ capital markets is “under strain,” a committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce on Monday proposed a series of steps to ease the regulatory burdens for U.S. companies. The report, which noted a “substantial decrease” in the number of initial public offerings in the U.S., called for the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to be folded into the 1934 law that created the Securities and Exchange Commission and urged companies to stop giving quarterly earnings guidance.

headline.main: Report Urges Changes to Burnish U.S. Markets

abstract: As the markets dropped sharply last week, sending volume soaring and backing up trades handled by the New York Stock Exchange, at least one stock market player was resting easy. Bats Trading, an upstart electronic trading system based in Kansas City, Mo., said it handled the volatility with none of the glitches that others did.
lead_paragraph: As the markets dropped sharply last week, sending volume soaring and backing up trades handled by the New York Stock Exchange, at least one stock market player was resting easy. Bats Trading, an upstart electronic trading system based in Kansas City, Mo., said it handled the volatility with none of the glitches that others did.

headline.main: Smaller Exchange Avoids Big Problems

abstract: A federal judge gave final approval Friday to a $72.5 million settlement between Arthur Andersen and investors who sued the accounting firm over its role in the 2001 collapse of Enron. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon signed the final order at a brief hearing held in Houston, effectively ending the now defunct accounting firm’s involvement in the $40 billion class-action lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge gave final approval Friday to a $72.5 million settlement between Arthur Andersen and investors who sued the accounting firm over its role in the 2001 collapse of Enron. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon signed the final order at a brief hearing held in Houston, effectively ending the now defunct accounting firm’s involvement in the $40 billion class-action lawsuit.

headline.main: Arthur Anderson Settles With Enron Investors

abstract: Analysts are betting that Goldman Sachs, which has reported record earnings and revenue for the past three years, may see a slow-down in the first quarter. The investment bank, whose stock has surged 36 percent in the last 12 months, far outpacing its rivals, is expected to post solid, if not stellar results, when it announces its results this week.
lead_paragraph: Analysts are betting that Goldman Sachs, which has reported record earnings and revenue for the past three years, may see a slow-down in the first quarter. The investment bank, whose stock has surged 36 percent in the last 12 months, far outpacing its rivals, is expected to post solid, if not stellar results, when it announces its results this week.

headline.main: After Record Run, Goldman Profits to Slow, Analysts Say

abstract: The upcoming criminal fraud trial in Chicago of Conrad M. Black, the former head of Hollinger International who faces more than 90 years in jail if convicted, has all the makings of good theater. First there is Mr. Black himself, a larger-than-life figure whose baroque vocabulary and towering demeanor can seem straight out of Dickens. Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials facing the rest of their years behind bars, Mr. Black has gone very public – giving interviews and speeches, writing articles chastising his accusers and vowing not only exoneration but a comeback.
lead_paragraph: The upcoming criminal fraud trial in Chicago of Conrad M. Black, the former head of Hollinger International who faces more than 90 years in jail if convicted, has all the makings of good theater. First there is Mr. Black himself, a larger-than-life figure whose baroque vocabulary and towering demeanor can seem straight out of Dickens. Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials facing the rest of their years behind bars, Mr. Black has gone very public – giving interviews and speeches, writing articles chastising his accusers and vowing not only exoneration but a comeback.

headline.main: Facing Fraud Trial, Conrad Black Flouts the Rules

abstract: A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenberg’s company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.
lead_paragraph: A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenberg’s company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.

headline.main: Greenberg’s P.R. Firm Sues for $2 Million

abstract: Akzo Nobel said Monday it would sell its pharmaceuticals unit Organon BioSciences to Schering-Plough for 11 billion euros ($14.5 billion), dropping its previously announced plans to hold an initial public offering for the business. The deal bulks up United States-based Schering-Plough, whose chief executive has made no secret of his desire to find acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Akzo Nobel said Monday it would sell its pharmaceuticals unit Organon BioSciences to Schering-Plough for 11 billion euros ($14.5 billion), dropping its previously announced plans to hold an initial public offering for the business. headline.main: Schering-Plough to Pay $14.5 Billion for Drugs Unit

abstract: Donald Trump’s Trump Entertainment Resorts has hired Merrill Lynch to help the company evaluate its options, which might include selling a single casino or even the entire company, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger. Other possibilities for the Atlantic City casino operator include an equity offering to raise cash or even taking the company private, the report said.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s Trump Entertainment Resorts has hired Merrill Lynch to help the company evaluate its options, which might include selling a single casino or even the entire company, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger. Other possibilities for the Atlantic City casino operator include an equity offering to raise cash or even taking the company private, the report said.

headline.main: Trump Resorts Hires Merrill as Adviser, Report Says

abstract: Dollar General, a discount retailer with more than 8,000 stores in the United States, said Monday it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $7.3 billion, including about $380 million in assumed debt. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $22 in cash for each Dollar General share, or about 31 percent more than the shares’ closing price on Friday, Dollar General said. The company’s board has unanimously approved the transaction and is urging shareholders to vote in favor of it.
lead_paragraph: Dollar General, a discount retailer with more than 8,000 stores in the United States, said Monday it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $7.3 billion, including about $380 million in assumed debt. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $22 in cash for each Dollar General share, or about 31 percent more than the shares’ closing price on Friday, Dollar General said. The company’s board has unanimously approved the transaction and is urging shareholders to vote in favor of it.

headline.main: Dollar General Agrees to $6.9 Billion Buyout

abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe’s largest consumer electronics maker, said Friday it plans to sell its 16.2 percent stake in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing over the next few years. The stake is valued at around $8.5 billion. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing is the world’s biggest contract chip maker by revenue.
lead_paragraph: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe’s largest consumer electronics maker, said Friday it plans to sell its 16.2 percent stake in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing over the next few years. The stake is valued at around $8.5 billion. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing is the world’s biggest contract chip maker by revenue.

headline.main: Royal Philips to Sell Taiwan Chipmaker Stake

abstract: UnitedHealth Group, the health-insurance giant, said on Monday it would acquire Sierra Health Services for $2.6 billion, or $43.50 in cash per share, to help it expand in the fast-growing Southwest. Sierra provides health benefits and services to 310,000 members in Nevada and 320,000 customers throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, the health-insurance giant, said on Monday it would acquire Sierra Health Services for $2.6 billion, or $43.50 in cash per share, to help it expand in the fast-growing Southwest. Sierra provides health benefits and services to 310,000 members in Nevada and 320,000 customers throughout the United States.

headline.main: UnitedHealth to Buy Sierra Health for $2.6 Billion

abstract: There was nothing top secret about this deal: Confirming several previous reports, Ford Motor said Monday that it would sell its Aston Martin, known as the sports car of choice for James Bond, to a group including racing mogul David Richards and two Kuwaiti investment firms. The transaction values Aston Martin at $925 million, but Ford will keep a stake in the unit vauled at $77 million, the company said.

The transaction values Aston Martin at $925 million, but Ford will keep a stake in the unit vauled at $77 million, the company said.

headline.main: Ford to Sell Aston Martin in $925 Million Deal

abstract: Acknowledging its weakened position, Express Scripts said Monday that it woud not raise its offer for rival Caremark Rx without the chance to conduct due diligence, which Caremark has refused to allow. The announcement appears to put CVS in a position to win the bitter takeover feud for Caremark, a bitter fight that has played out in public and in the courts since December. In a press release, Express Scripts criticized Caremark’s merger process as “flawed” and continued to urge Caremark’s shareholders to vote against the merger with CVS, the nation’s largest drugstore chain.
lead_paragraph: Acknowledging its weakened position, Express Scripts said Monday that it woud not raise its offer for rival Caremark Rx without the chance to conduct due diligence, which Caremark has refused to allow. In a press release, Express Scripts criticized Caremark’s merger process as “flawed” and continued to urge Caremark’s shareholders to vote against the merger with CVS, the nation’s largest drugstore chain.

headline.main: Express Scripts Says It Can’t Raise Caremark Bid

abstract: They seem to have automated everything else, so why not insider trading? BusinessWeek reported Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission, the nation’s top markets regulator, is planning to take a close look at automated trading plans, which are often set up for executives as a way to buy and sell stock of their own companies. The S.E.C. is said to be looking for evidence that these automated programs are being used (or abused) to facilitate stock sales based on inside information — which is just what they are supposed to prevent.
lead_paragraph: They seem to have automated everything else, so why not insider trading? The S.E.C. is said to be looking for evidence that these automated programs are being used (or abused) to facilitate stock sales based on inside information — which is just what they are supposed to prevent.

headline.main: Well-Timed Insider Sales Draw Attention

abstract: Morgan Stanley shows no sign of a waning interest in hedge funds. The investment bank said Monday that it has bought a minority stake in Abax Global Capital, a startup cofounded by Citadel Investment Group veterans that will focus on Asian investments. Morgan Stanley did not disclose the size of the stake or the value of the deal.

abstract: The latest “intrusion” tactic, making good money in worthless options
snippet: The latest “intrusion” tactic, making good money in worthless options
lead_paragraph: The latest enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to “intruded” brokerage accounts has a nice switch: In addition to having the defrauded investors buy shares of thinly traded companies you never heard of, this group, of three traders from India, also made good money trading in worthless options of a company almost everyone knows: Google.

headline.main: Quadruple Your Money in Worthless Options

abstract: Since leaving Miramax to cofound The Weinstein Company, Harvey Weinstein has invested in an assortment of niche media plays, some of which are firmly outside the movie industry in which he made his name. His firm, which describes itself as a “multimedia company,” bought cable arts channel Ovation and invested in aSmallWorld.net, an invitation-only social-networking Web site for adults. The movie mogul’s latest potential target — a fashion company — is even farther afield.
