abstract: Wachovia Securities, Wachovia’s investment banking arm, said Monday that it hired two managing directors to cover the media and communications industries. William Bundy, who had been at J.P. Morgan Chase, will work in Wachovia’s media and communications investment banking group, and John Schwarz, previously of Lazard, will be in the mergers and acquisitions group.

abstract: Shareholders of Calpine, the bankrupt energy giant, are lining up some high-powered advisers as they try to influence the company’s Chapter 11 case. Shareholders are typically relegated to the sidelines in bankruptcy, under the theory that there will be nothing left for them after creditors get paid. But members of Calpine’s official committee of equity holders think there will be something left in the till — and so, apparently, does their financial adviser, Perella Weinberg Partners.

headline.main: In Calpine Case, Adviser Puts Its Fee on the Line

abstract: The battle for Caremark Rx seemed all but over Monday after Express Scripts said that under current conditions it could not raise its $26.3 billion offer for the rival drug benefits manager. Many analysts concluded that CVS‘s $26 billion bid would win support of Caremark’s shareholders, with Wachovia analyst Matt Perry declaring: “If the two offers are within approximately 5 percent of each other, Caremark shareholders are likely to approve the CVS offer.”
lead_paragraph: The battle for Caremark Rx seemed all but over Monday after Express Scripts said that under current conditions it could not raise its $26.3 billion offer for the rival drug benefits manager. headline.main: Express Scripts Shares Rise on Possible End to Caremark Battle

abstract: It is shaping up to be a busy month for Michael Eisner, the former head of Disney. Less than a week after announcing it would help take baseball-card maker Topps private, Mr. Eisner’s investment firm, Tornante, said it was launching Vuguru, an independent studio to produce and distribute original programming on the Web. Mr. Eisner has shown an interest in Web-based video with his previous investment in Veoh Networks, a video-sharing site that competes with the much more widely visited YouTube.

Mr. Eisner has shown an interest in Web-based video with his previous investment in Veoh Networks, a video-sharing site that competes with the much more widely visited YouTube.

abstract: Much is being made of venture capitalist John Doerr breaking down into tears as he talked about global warming on Thursday during the TED conference in Monterey, Calif. But what may be more disturbing is what he actually said: “I’m scared. I don’t think we’re going to make it.”

abstract: British pharmacy chain Alliance Boots rejected a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) buyout offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its own executive deputy chairman, saying the bid tabled only a few hours before was too low. Shares in Alliance Boots, formed last year from the merger of retailer Boots and drugs wholesaler Alliance Unichem, were up 7 percent at 997 pence.

abstract: The most famous surviving words from the ancient Greek Battle of Thermopylae have been “molon labe,” the defiant taunt by 300 Spartans to their numerically superior Persian adversaries. Translated, it means roughly “Come and take them,” referring to their weapons. This past weekend, it could also have referred to seats at movie theaters, as viewers swarmed cinemas to help Warner Brothers’ “300” shatter box-office records.

abstract: Money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity that are three to five times those of other investments, a new study said.
snippet: Money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity that are three to five times those of other investments, a new study said.
lead_paragraph: Money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity that are three to five times those of other investments, according to a study being published today. But the study also concluded that the information technology industry itself was unlikely to be a big source of new jobs.

headline.main: Study Says Computers Give Big Boosts to Productivity

abstract: When strangers in strange lands impress you with unexpected care and generosity, you start to wonder about your own impact as a traveler.

lead_paragraph: Travel often turns my expectations upside down. In 1999, I visited Iran with a small group of Americans to watch a total eclipse of the sun. On the afternoon of the event, I found myself alone in Esfahan’s vast Khomeini Square: one American among 50,000 Iranians.

headline.main: Passing Through but Leaving a Lasting Impression

abstract: Oxbow Carbon and Minerals Holdings raised its offer for the Great Lakes Carbon Income Fund to about 657 million Canadian dollars ($562 million), topping a higher bid from Rain Commodities and extending a bidding war for Great Lakes, a producer of carbon used to make aluminum. Oxbow raised its bid to 13.50 Canadian dollars a share for Great Lakes Carbon, which was above Rain’s bid of 13.25 Canadian dollars a share, Oxbow said. Oxbow, a unit of the privately held energy company Oxbow Group, bid 13 Canadian dollars a share on Wednesday. Oxbow is based in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Rain Commodities is based in India. Shares in Great Lakes Carbon trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

abstract: FLYERTALK.COM SOLD FlyerTalk.com, the Web site with scores of vibrant forums on frequent-flier programs, loyalty points and travel, has been sold to Internet Brands by Randy Petersen, who founded the site almost nine years ago. Mr. Petersen will continue as a consultant for four years. In e-mail messages to members and to site moderators, Mr. Petersen said he decided to sell only after “plenty of sleepless nights.” Other travel companies that had expressed interest, he said, included American Express, Expedia, Travelocity and Condé Nast Interactive. Internet Brands operates e-commerce sites for cars, real estate, mortgages and travel. Mr. Petersen said he chose Internet Brands, which was not the highest bidder, because “they weren’t interested in making any changes” to FlyerTalk.com.

abstract: Four Seasons Hotels, the world’s largest operator of luxury hotels, reported a fourth-quarter profit on higher room revenue. Four Seasons, based in Toronto, said profit was $16.9 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.8 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. The company said it had higher costs in the year-earlier period related to retirement benefits and lower revenue after ending its lease for the Pierre in New York. Revenue rose 19 percent, to $69.8 million, from $58.5 million, because of an increase in hotel management and ownership fees. Revenue for each available room worldwide rose 14 percent, to $258.13; at properties in the United States, it was up 8.4 percent, to $297.83. Four Seasons agreed last month to be sold to a group of private investors.

abstract: In what will no doubt be unwelcome news for Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, Apax Partners Worldwide has announced that it will stop investing in start-up companies to focus solely on leveraged buyouts after it raised a record 10 billion euro ($13 billion) takeover fund. “Our next fund will be 100 percent buyouts,” Martin Halusa, chief executive of Apax, said last week after giving a presentation to the Washington State Investment Board in Olympia. “Our venture results have been very volatile, and our focus is on the more stable end of the business.”

abstract: British private equity leaders, determined to change the perception of themselves as vultures and locusts, stayed on point Monday. Speaking at the annual dinner of the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association, Rod Selkirk, the association’s chairman, said private equity takeovers were responsible for strong growth in British jobs and exports over the past five years. He said the industry had also benefited workers’ pension funds, because their investments in private equity funds had made double-digit gains.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three men Monday with hacking into online brokerage accounts based in the United States, primarily from Thailand and India, and manipulating stock prices to turn a profit for themselves. The civil charges, brought in a Nebraska federal court, claim the men allegedly used stolen identity information to pose as online buyers, inflate the value of the stock, and then sell their own shares at a higher price.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three men Monday with hacking into online brokerage accounts based in the United States, primarily from Thailand and India, and manipulating stock prices to turn a profit for themselves. The civil charges, brought in a Nebraska federal court, claim the men allegedly used stolen identity information to pose as online buyers, inflate the value of the stock, and then sell their own shares at a higher price.

headline.main: S.E.C. Charges Hackers With Stock Manipulation

abstract: Procter & Gamble said on Monday it had agreed to sell its European tissue operations to a Swedish hygiene and paper product maker SCA for 512 million euros ($672 million). SCA said the acquisition would give it a batch of new brands, including Tempo, the market leader in paper handkerchiefs in western Europe and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Procter & Gamble said on Monday it had agreed to sell its European tissue operations to a Swedish hygiene and paper product maker SCA for 512 million euros ($672 million). SCA said the acquisition would give it a batch of new brands, including Tempo, the market leader in paper handkerchiefs in western Europe and Hong Kong.

headline.main: Procter & Gamble Disposes of European Tissue Business

abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

headline.main: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?

abstract: Merrill Lynch was looking at a possible bid for CanWest Global‘s stake in the Australian broadcaster Ten Network, Reuters reported. Canada’s CanWest has a 56.4 percent stake in Ten and had initially hoped to get up to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion) for the holding, but the sale has apparently made slow progress. Ten has a market value of about 3 billion Australian dollars, including the CanWest stake, based on the latest share price.

Canada’s CanWest has a 56.4 percent stake in Ten and had initially hoped to get up to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion) for the holding, but the sale has apparently made slow progress. Ten has a market value of about 3 billion Australian dollars, including the CanWest stake, based on the latest share price.

headline.main: Merrill Lynch Tunes In to Australian TV Auction, Report Says

abstract: More than $30 billion in just four deals announced Monday may represent a big payday for investment-banking advisers, potentially shaking up the industry’s league tables as the industry enters the home stretch, MarketWatch notes. The Web site estimated that the total fees could ring in between $30 million and $100 million. Check out the breakdown after the jump.

headline.main: Merger Monday May Boost Banks’ League Rankings

abstract: Initial public offerings from tech maker BigBand Networks, commodities risk management firm FCStone and medicine maker Tongjitang Chinese Medicines face a choppy new issues market this week. Roiled by the big sell-off two weeks ago, the I.P.O. market is attempting to find its footing after a couple of big stumbles by recent deals.
lead_paragraph: Initial public offerings from tech maker BigBand Networks, commodities risk management firm FCStone and medicine maker Tongjitang Chinese Medicines face a choppy new issues market this week. Roiled by the big sell-off two weeks ago, the I.P.O. market is attempting to find its footing after a couple of big stumbles by recent deals.

headline.main: Tough Market Ahead for This Week’s I.P.O.’s

abstract: In yet another bump in the road for the proposed buyout of TXU, a report has found that the company manipulated the Texas electric market in 2005, costing consumers $70 million and giving the utility $20 million in extra profits. TXU, the largest power generator in Texas, sold power to the market at inflated prices and caused electricity prices to rise 15.5 percent during a four-month summer stretch, according to an outside expert whose report was released by state regulators on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In yet another bump in the road for the proposed buyout of TXU, a report has found that the company manipulated the Texas electric market in 2005, costing consumers $70 million and giving the utility $20 million in extra profits. TXU, the largest power generator in Texas, sold power to the market at inflated prices and caused electricity prices to rise 15.5 percent during a four-month summer stretch, according to an outside expert whose report was released by state regulators on Monday.

headline.main: State Monitor Finds TXU Abused Texas Power Market

abstract: Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits.

headline.main: Bush Aides and Business Meet on Shift in Regulation

abstract: The Wall Street banks and brokerage firms that just a few months ago welcomed New Century Financial with open arms and gave it credit lines worth billions of dollars have quickly shut off the spigot, forcing it ever closer to bankruptcy. New Century, one of the biggest mortgage lenders to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit, said in a securities filing Monday that all its lenders had frozen their credit lines and were demanding that it buy back $8.4 billion in loans that it issued using the money it borrowed from the banks – money New Century says it does not have.

headline.main: Lender Faces Credit Crisis With Banks

abstract: the film producer Harvey Weinstein is casting himself in the role of fashion industry magnate.
lead_paragraph: the film producer Harvey Weinstein is casting himself in the role of fashion industry magnate.

headline.main: Film Producer and Partners Buy Halston

abstract: The Children’s Investment Fund is turning up the heat on Electric Power Development to triple its dividend, marking the first time the British activist hedge fund has targeted a Japanesey company. Known as TCI, the fund has urged the country’s largest electricity wholesaler, often called J-Power, to increase its year-end dividend to 100 yen from its current plans for 30 yen. With a 9.9 percent stake, TCI is J-Power’s largest shareholder.

With a 9.9 percent stake, TCI is J-Power’s largest shareholder.

headline.main: Britain’s TCI Makes Noise at J-Power

abstract: Jerry Salzman, the longtime outside counsel for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom on Monday, as the law firm he cofounded is closing down after 40 years. Mr. Salzman is leaving Freeman, Freeman & Salzman months after the exchange agreed to acquire CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in an $8 billion deal that could create the world’s largest futures exchange. Skadden represented the Merc in that deal.

Skadden represented the Merc in that deal.

headline.main: Chicago Merc Counsel Joins Skadden

abstract: The 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion) takeover bid for Australia’s Qantas Airways hit a rough patch on Tuesday as some large shareholders remained cool on the deal. The Australian Financial Review reported that UBS and Balanced Equity Management, who together have enough clout to kill a deal, have pressed the airline’s management to release a report explaining why the bid led by Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group does not undervalue the company.
lead_paragraph: The 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion) takeover bid for Australia’s Qantas Airways hit a rough patch on Tuesday as some large shareholders remained cool on the deal. headline.main: Qantas Shareholders Pose Obstacle to Deal

abstract: After Nikko Cordial‘s four biggest shareholders dismissed its first bid as too low, Citigroup on Tuesday raised its offer for the Japanese brokerage by 26 percent to $13.4 billion. Citigroup’s new bid now values Nikko, one of Japan’s largest brokerage firms, at 1,700 yen ($14.48) a share, up from 1,350 yen.
lead_paragraph: After Nikko Cordial‘s four biggest shareholders dismissed its first bid as too low, Citigroup on Tuesday raised its offer for the Japanese brokerage by 26 percent to $13.4 billion. Citigroup’s new bid now values Nikko, one of Japan’s largest brokerage firms, at 1,700 yen ($14.48) a share, up from 1,350 yen.

headline.main: Citi Raises Bid for Japanese Brokerage to $13.4 Billion

abstract: Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter despite growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter despite growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

headline.main: Goldman Posts Record Quarterly Profits

abstract: Carl C. Icahn is getting tough with WCI Communities. The billionaire financier said Tuesday he would offer to buy the residential homebuilder for $22 share and if the company were to resist, he made it clear that he would try to throw out the board and get the deal done regardless. WCI is just one of several companies that Mr. Icahn has been prodding in recent months in what has been an especially active period for the activist investor.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn is getting tough with WCI Communities. WCI is just one of several companies that Mr. Icahn has been prodding in recent months in what has been an especially active period for the activist investor.

headline.main: Icahn, in Battle Mode, Offers to Buy Homebuilder

abstract: While hedge funds confidently flex their muscles in the markets and in boardrooms, in Washington they are experiencing the awkward growing pains of a relatively new industry coming to grips with its own power. Some hedge funds like D. E. Shaw and Cerberus Capital Management have spent time and money in the capital, but most funds have been content to hope Washington will not rear its regulatory head.
lead_paragraph: While hedge funds confidently flex their muscles in the markets and in boardrooms, in Washington they are experiencing the awkward growing pains of a relatively new industry coming to grips with its own power. Some hedge funds like D. E. Shaw and Cerberus Capital Management have spent time and money in the capital, but most funds have been content to hope Washington will not rear its regulatory head.

headline.main: In Lobbying Dance, Hedge Funds Are Still Learning the Steps

abstract: Moving deeper into the alternative-asset management business, Lehman Brothers said Tuesday it had bought a 20 percent stake in D.E. Shaw, one of the largest hedge funds in the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it follows similar transactions at Lehman and other Wall Street firms that want to be able to offer their clients greater access to these private pools of capital. Morgan Stanley has been especially active: It announced Monday that it had bought a piece of Abax Global Capital, its fifth hedge-fund investment in the past few months.

headline.main: Lehman Buys Stake in Large Hedge Fund

abstract: The diagnosis for Express Scripts‘ $26.3 billion bid for Caremark Rx is getting even grimmer. On Tuesday, a proxy advisory firm came out in favor of the proposed merger of Caremark, a drug-benefits manager, with drugstore chain CVS, reversing its previous position that shareholders should reject the deal.
lead_paragraph: The diagnosis for Express Scripts‘ $26.3 billion bid for Caremark Rx is getting even grimmer. headline.main: Proxy Firm’s Flip May Bury Express Scripts Bid

abstract: Though some reports have said that Samuel Zell’s bid for Tribune is a solid hit, it may be a fielders choice of sorts; but in any case, the ball is still in play. Mr. Zell, who completed the record-breaking sale of his Equity Office Properties Trust last month, has said that he intends on keeping the media conglomerate together, including its newspaper and television properties and the Chicago Cubs.

abstract: Is Nelson Peltz trying to satisfy his sweet tooth? Responding to rumors Tuesday, Cadbury Schweppes said that Mr. Peltz has amassed a stake of nearly 3 percent in Cadbury, the world’s largest candy and soft drink maker. Shares in the company on the London Stock Exchange were up 10.6 percent, at 602.50 pence each, valuing the company at about 12.6 billion pounds ($24.3 billion).

abstract: Clear Channel Communications has been quiet about its fallback options in the event that shareholders shoot down its $18.7 billion proposal to go private. But with investor opposition building, such a scenario seems increasingly likely. And Victor Miller, an analyst at Bear Stearns, sees plenty of possibilities for what the nation’s largest radio broadcaster could do next.
lead_paragraph: Clear Channel Communications has been quiet about its fallback options in the event that shareholders shoot down its $18.7 billion proposal to go private. But with investor opposition building, such a scenario seems increasingly likely. And Victor Miller, an analyst at Bear Stearns, sees plenty of possibilities for what the nation’s largest radio broadcaster could do next.

headline.main: What Is Clear Channel’s Plan B?

abstract: Spirit Finance, a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said on Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium led by Australia’s Macquarie Bank for about $1.6 billion. The group offered $14.50 per share in cash, a premium of about 11 percent over Spirit Finance’s closing price of $13.05 on Monday. The deal is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, Spirit Finance said, though a provision lets it solicit other bids through April 9.
lead_paragraph: Spirit Finance, a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said on Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium led by Australia’s Macquarie Bank for about $1.6 billion. The deal is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, Spirit Finance said, though a provision lets it solicit other bids through April 9.

headline.main: Macquarie to Buy Spirit Finance

abstract: “It’s a really good time to be an M.B.A.,” Andy Chan, assistant dean and director of the M.B.A. Career Management Center at Stanford University, tells Bloomberg News. How good? Last year, graduates of Harvard Business School averaged a record $186,174 in starting pay, while new M.B.A.’s from Stanford’s business school earned an average of $183,000. Starting pay for graduates from the top business schools may rise further, thanks to intense competition for them among big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

abstract: Sourcefire‘s successful initial offering last week may have represented a turning point in the buyout trend among makers of security software. The 451 Group, which researches the enterprise technology sector, expects a “steady flow” of computer security companies to go public over the next few quarters. Among them: Postini, Barracuda Networks, AcrSight and Fortinet.

abstract: In an apparent effort to avoid defeat, Clear Channel Communications on Wednesday pushed back both the record date and the voting date for a proposed $18.7 billion management-led buyout. Now, the record date — which determines the shareholders eligible to vote on the deal — has been delayed to March 23, and the vote itself moved to April 19 from March 21.
lead_paragraph: In an apparent effort to avoid defeat, Clear Channel Communications on Wednesday pushed back both the record date and the voting date for a proposed $18.7 billion management-led buyout. Now, the record date — which determines the shareholders eligible to vote on the deal — has been delayed to March 23, and the vote itself moved to April 19 from March 21.

headline.main: Clear Channel Delays Vote on Buyout

Algoma negotiated with potential buyers in 2005 and renewed negotiations in February 2006 without reaching an agreement.

abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada agreed to buy a money manager J. B. Hanauer & Company of New Jersey, in its sixth acquisition in the United States in the last year. Details of the purchase, which is expected to be completed in May, were not disclosed, Royal Bank said. J. B. Hanauer, created in 1931, specializes in fixed-income and wealth management services. The company, based in Parsippany, has five offices in three states, with about 300 employees including 147 financial consultants, and almost $10 billion in assets under administration.

abstract: Massachusetts Secretary of State William F. Galvin said Tuesday he had ordered UBS Securities and Bear Stearns to turn over documents concerning their analysts’ recommendations on subprime lenders such as New Century Financial. abstract: After raising its offer for the Japanese brokerage Nikko Cordial by 26 percent on Tuesday, Citigroup said Wednesday that its offer is final. abstract: d Salzgitter, a German steel company, has dropped out of talks to buy a Canadian rival, Algoma Steel, after word of the secret negotiations leaked, driving up the price of a takeover and piquing the interest of other potential suitors. While Salzgitter has walked away four weeks after starting talks, there are other “interested parties” that surfaced after news of the Salzgitter discussions became public last month, Algoma said Tuesday, adding that it plans to enter into negotiations with them in hopes of salvaging a sale.

abstract: The medical products maker Baxter International said Wednesday its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional $2 billion of its common stock. The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said the repurchase would be executed “upon completion of its existing share repurchase program.” Baxter said it has about $800 million of “remaining authorization under the $1.7 billion program” the board approved in February 2006.

abstract: the financial services firm Cantor Fitzgerald has merged its previously separate United States pollutant brokerage with its carbon brokering business to try and cash in on expected expansion in carbon markets. Cantor wants to put its environmental brokerage, which until now has focused on markets in pollutants like sulfur and nitrous dioxide, to work in emerging carbon markets. A power shift in the Congress last autumn has raised hopes for a national carbon market, leading to a surge of interest among investors.

headline.main: Cantor Bets on Carbon Market

abstract: Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of “massive copyright infringement.” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.

headline.main: Viacom Sues Google for $1 Billion

abstract: Travelport, a travel-services company owned by private equity firms, said Wednesday it plans to sell part of its Orbitz Worldwide unit in an initial public offering, which it expects to complete in the third quarter. The size of the stake to be sold and the price are still undetermined, Travelport said.
lead_paragraph: Travelport, a travel-services company owned by private equity firms, said Wednesday it plans to sell part of its Orbitz Worldwide unit in an initial public offering, which it expects to complete in the third quarter. abstract: Lehman Brothers on Wednesday reported a $1.15 billion profit in its fiscal first quarter, up nearly 6 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago. Net revenue rose 13 percent, to $5 billion, Lehman said. Separately, Lehman’s stock posted its biggest decline in about five years on Tuesday amid concerns about rising mortgage defaults.
lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers on Wednesday reported a $1.15 billion profit in its fiscal first quarter, up nearly 6 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago. headline.main: Lehman Profit Rose in First Quarter

abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase is going Hollywood — all the way. Already one of the major players in structuring and financing entertainment deals, the investment bank is planning a unit aimed at advising moviemakers on everything from financing arrangements to merchandising deals, according to The Wall Street Journal. The Journal noted that the plan is part of J.P. Morgan’s effort to grow its business without relying on acquisitions.

abstract: Home Depot‘s chief executive, Frank Blake, offered a reality check Wednesday to those who are hoping his company will soon become the biggest buyout target in history. “We’re not thinking about going private,” Mr. Blake said at a Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce conference. “We’re very pleased with the capital structure we have.” There has been speculation that Home Depot’s stalled stock price and its valuable real-estate assets could make the home-improvement retailer an attractive acquisition candidate for private equity firms. With a market capitalization of about $76 billion, though, Home Depot would be quite a tall order for even a posse of firms flush with cash.

With a market capitalization of about $76 billion, though, Home Depot would be quite a tall order for even a posse of firms flush with cash.

abstract: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.

abstract: Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company. abstract: Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDO’s and CMBS’s. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner, who reports that “bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans.”

abstract: Antigovernment crusaders are often the biggest obstacles to the achievement of economic efficiency.

abstract: The Smurfit Kappa Group, the world’s largest maker of cardboard boxes, raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.7 billion) Wednesday in Ireland’s biggest initial public offering in almost eight years. The shares were priced at 16.5 euros apiece, valuing the company at about 3.4 billion euros.
lead_paragraph: The Smurfit Kappa Group, the world’s largest maker of cardboard boxes, raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.7 billion) Wednesday in Ireland’s biggest initial public offering in almost eight years. The shares were priced at 16.5 euros apiece, valuing the company at about 3.4 billion euros.

abstract: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market may throw a wrench into H&R Block‘s plans to sell its subprime mortgage group. While its tax business is showing signs of improvement, H&R Block cannot get rid of its subprime mortgage group, Option One, fast enough. H&R Block disclosed yesterday that its loss widened to $60.3 million in the third quarter as a result of continued problems at Option One, which the company put on the block last year.

headline.main: Sale of H&R Block Loan Division May Experience Turbulence

abstract: Merrill Lynch is considering providing debt financing for a private equity group hoping to mount a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid for Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, The Guardian reported. Merrill’s interest in backing a new bid emerged just a day after it quit as Alliance Boots’ joint broker and two days after Alliance rejected an initial bid of 10 pounds a share from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the deputy chairman of Boots, Stefano Pessina.

abstract: An investment fund of Australia’s Macquarie Bank has agreed to buy the car-parking facilities of Britain’s National Car Parks for 790 million pounds ($1.52 billion) from a private equity firm, the 3i Group. 3i will retain NCP’s car-clamping and towing services unit following the demerger of the group. NCP operates about 850 car parks with about 50,000 spaces, accounting for more than half Britain’s off-street parking market, and is the largest provider of spaces at airports and railway stations.

headline.main: Macquarie Buys British Car Park Unit from 3i

abstract: If the first day of jury selection for the former press tycoon Conrad M. Black is any indication, then many in the potential jury pool have not forgotten the corporate scandals of a few years ago. Judge Amy J. St. Eve began the process on Wednesday of winnowing down a pool of more than 100 potential jurors in the criminal fraud trial of Mr. Black and three former associates in United States District Court by asking them about their attitudes toward money, titles and tax loopholes.

abstract: The IntercontinentalExchange said Thursday that it offered to merge with the Chicago Board of Trade, seeking to derail that exchange’s agreement to combine with its hometown rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The surprise bid, valued at about $9.9 billion in stock, came just a few weeks before shareholders of CBOT, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, were scheduled to vote on its merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

abstract: Bear Stearns, Wall Street’s leading underwriter of mortgage-backed securities, said Thursday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter rose 8 percent from a year ago, but problems in the risky subprime loan sector hurt mortgage-related revenue. abstract: General Electric and the Blackstone Group said Thursday that they would buy PHH, a financial-services and mortgage provider, for $31.50 a share, or $1.8 billion. The price represents a 13 percent premium to PHH’s closing stock price of $27.81 on Wednesday. According to the terms of the deal, G.E. Capital will acquire PHH, holding onto the PHH Arval fleet management services unit while selling PHH Mortgage, a residential mortgage servicer, to Blackstone after the transaction closes.

abstract: Has the IntercontinentalExchange sparked a bidding war? Investors seem to hope so. Shares of CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, rose 15 percent, to $191 in early trading Thursday after Intercontinental, an electronic marketplace for energy trades, announced its offer to merge with the exchange in a $9.9 billion stock swap. The surge put shares of CBOT, which is in the final stages of a merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, above the value of Intercontinental’s bid, based on an exchange ratio of 1.42 Intercontinental shares for each CBOT share. (That comes out to $186.38 based on Incontinental’s recent price of $131.25.)

abstract: It may end up being largely symbolic, but Calpers, the country’s biggest pension fund and a major force on corporate governance issues, said it voted its shares against drugstore chain CVS‘s $23.5 billion acquisition of drug-benefits manager Caremark Rx. Objecting from both sides of the deal, Calpers said it opposed the transaction with its 3.1 million CVS shares and 2.1 million Caremark shares. Nevertheless, CVS shareholders approved the deal Thursday, leaving Friday’s vote by Caremark shareholders as the final hurdle.

abstract: Cisco‘s acquisition strategy has been a bit of a puzzle lately. The company, best known for making routers that direct network traffic, got Silicon Valley talking earlier this month when it bought the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site. On Thursday, Cisco announced another offbeat (and much bigger) deal: the $3.2 billion purchase of WebEx, a Web-based video conferencing service.

abstract: A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airline’s earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate. The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion). At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed. “The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny,” said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.

abstract: Luxury home prices in London rose at an annual rate of 31 percent in February, the fastest pace in 28 years. The average price of London’s most expensive houses and apartments gained 2.6 percent on a monthly basis, according to data compiled by Knight Frank, a real estate broker based in London. “Prices in central London have for the past two years been growing at three times the rate” of the rest of Britain, said Liam Bailey, the partner in charge of residential research at Knight Frank.

abstract: The All Nippon Airways Company had its offices in Los Angeles searched for nine hours yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to a statement from the carrier. The FBI declined to say why the office was searched. ”We don’t know why they raided the office, but we confirmed with our staff there that it wasn’t anything to do with the operation of the aircraft or terrorism,” a spokesman at All Nippon, Rob Henderson, said. The customer service center in Los Angeles is the headquarters of the airline’s North American operations and is responsible for passenger and cargo sales for the western and southern United States.

abstract: Nissan Motor plans to cut production at two plants in Japan from April 2 until the end of June because of weaker demand. Nissan will cut a shift on a production line in Kanagawa and in Tochigi Prefectures, a spokesman, Yuichi Nakagawa, said. Each plant has two lines. The plant in Kanagawa makes subcompacts like the March, and the Tochigi plant builds Skyline sedans and other vehicles. Nissan’s domestic vehicle sales, excluding minicars, fell for a 17th straight month in February.

abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange may find it difficult to top Intercontinenental Exchange‘s $10 billion bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, analysts said yesterday. Under terms of ICE’s proposal, the Board of Trade’s shareholders would own about 51.5 percent of the combined company, which would be based in Chicago and have its headquarters at the Board of Trade’s storied building in the financial district.

abstract: General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors on Thursday that its performance was threatened by “ineffective” controls over financial reporting, including inadequately trained personnel and failure to obtain management’s approval for some transactions. The disclosure, made in G.M.’s annual report filed with federal regulators after a six-week delay, was the latest indication that the automaker is on shakier footing than first thought.

abstract: Silicon Valley’s technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries’ dominance with its green-tech innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. The cry has been raised by some of the Valley’ most stored venture capital firms such as Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Its principals, John Doerr in particular, have passionately (and tearfully) advocated development of alternative energies as a way to create energy independence and clean up the carbon-saturated atmosphere.

abstract: As a March 31 deadline nears for deciding the fate of Tribune, the proposal from Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, is falling from favor, according to The New York Times. The company, which has been on the auction block for more than five months, has all but dismissed three earlier bids. With Mr. Zell’s bid losing steam, The Times said, management is forced to reconsider how the company might restructure.

headline.main: One Proposal for Tribune Said to Lose Momentum

abstract: AOL founder Steven Case, supermarket magnate Ronald Burkle and venture capitalist Vinod Khosla are teaming up to invest in a company that could produce up to 1 billion gallons of ethanol a year in Brazil, according to The Wall Street Journal. Brazilian Renewable Energy Company, known as Benco, closed an initial $200 million round of funding this week, The Journal said. The deal is expected to be officially announced Thursday, according to the newspaper.

abstract: Takafumi Horie, the 34-year-old Internet tycoon once heralded as a symbol of new capitalism in Japan, was found guilty Friday morning by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor. He was sentenced to two years and six months. Mr. Horie, who had pleaded not guilty and argued that the trial was politically motivated, is expected to appeal. Prosecutors, who depicted Mr. Horie as a greedy and lawless figure who had manipulated the books to inflate his company’s stock price, had sought a four-year term.
lead_paragraph: Takafumi Horie, the 34-year-old Internet tycoon once heralded as a symbol of new capitalism in Japan, was found guilty Friday morning by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor. Prosecutors, who depicted Mr. Horie as a greedy and lawless figure who had manipulated the books to inflate his company’s stock price, had sought a four-year term.

headline.main: Ex-Internet Tycoon in Japan Guilty of Fraud

abstract: While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, don’t expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshire’s chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His company’s stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. But in a regulatory filing Thursday, the company said that “neither the profitability of Berkshire Hathaway nor the market value of its stock are to be considered in the compensation of any executive officer.”

headline.main: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett

abstract: In a ruling that could have broader effects on the booming buyout business, a Delaware judge faulted Netsmart Technologies for excluding strategic buyers from its sale process and ordered the company to delay a vote on its proposal to be acquired by two private equity firms. In a memo to clients, law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz called the decision, issued late Wednesday by Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Chancery Court, a “major opinion” on a deal that, although small, had many of the same elements as large private-equity transaction.
lead_paragraph: In a ruling that could have broader effects on the booming buyout business, a Delaware judge faulted Netsmart Technologies for excluding strategic buyers from its sale process and ordered the company to delay a vote on its proposal to be acquired by two private equity firms. Strine Jr. of Chancery Court, a “major opinion” on a deal that, although small, had many of the same elements as large private-equity transaction.

headline.main: Delaware Court Faults Sale to Buyout Firms

abstract: For Wall Street investment bankers who have been looking for inventive ways to spend last year’s record bonuses, there’s something new on the menu: the $1,000 pizza. Manhattan restauranteur Nino Selimaj has added the pricey pie — apparently the most expensive in the world — to the menu at Nino’s Bellisima on Second Ave., one of his six restaurants in the city. The uncooked pizza is topped with creme fraiche, chives, eight ounces of four different kinds of Petrossian caviar, four ounces of thinly sliced Maine lobster tail, salmon roe, and a little bit of spice with wasabi, according to CBS station WCBS-TV.

abstract: Texas’ state Senate approved legislation Thursday that would strip TXU of some of its power plants and increase state authority over TXU operations — including the right to approve the utility’s proposed $45 billion sale to a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group.

abstract: Chicago bank holding company Corus Bankshares said its sizeable investment in the stock of troubled subprime lender Fremont General has caused Corus’s position in Fremont to become “materially impaired,” which will spark a hefty pretax charge that could be $14.3 million or even higher. While Corus emphasized that it has “the intent and the ability to retain its Fremont investment,” the Chicago company believes that Fremont’s recent travails require the company to record a charge in the first quarter of 2007, to reflect the decline in the value of its Fremont investment.

abstract: China Agri-Industries, a producer of biofuel, has raised $410 million after pricing its initial public offering at the top of the range following hefty demand from both institutional and retail investors. The strong interest came despite the Hang Seng Index shedding more than a thousand points last week. The retail tranche was 607 times oversubscribed, making it the second most popular I.P.O. with the Hong Kong public this year after China Huiyuan Juice, which drew $27.7 billion worth of retail demand.
lead_paragraph: China Agri-Industries, a producer of biofuel, has raised $410 million after pricing its initial public offering at the top of the range following hefty demand from both institutional and retail investors. The retail tranche was 607 times oversubscribed, making it the second most popular I.P.O. with the Hong Kong public this year after China Huiyuan Juice, which drew $27.7 billion worth of retail demand.

headline.main: Chinese Biofuel Producer Sees Heavy Demand in I.P.O.

abstract: The research analyst who is a key player in the fight between Fairfax Holdings and short-selling hedge funds was indicted Thursday on wire fraud charges unrelated to the case. Spyro Contogouris was formally charged in relation to a case related to a prior real-estate job; he was arrested for that matter last November. Mr. Contogouris, whose criticism of Fairfax drove several hedge funds to sell short the company, is part of a $5 billion lawsuit filed by the Canadian insurer alleging a conspiracy to drive its stock price down.

abstract: Though many will be rooting for his conviction, Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, may escape from his trial on 42 insider-trading charges unscathed, according to lawyers watching the case. The trial, which begins March 19, will determine whether Mr. Nacchio is guilty of selling $101 million shares of Qwest from January to May of 2001 after getting internal warnings that the country’s fourth-largest phone company would fall short of revenue expectations.

headline.main: Weighing Nacchio’s Chances in Qwest Trial

abstract: Two British firms — Permira, the buyout group, and Centaurus, an activist hedge fund — have proposed a 4 billion euro ($5.3 billion) deal for Atos Origin, a French information technology services group, the Financial Times reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Atos confirmed Thursday that it had received an informal bid, but did not disclose the bidders. Shares in the company surged 25.2 percent to 49.50 euros a share on Thursday.

headline.main: Permira and Centaurus Are Said to Be in Talks with Atos

abstract: Jeffrey M. Johnson, the former Los Angeles Times publisher whose stand against Tribune led to his ouster, has taken a position with Ronald Burkle’s Yucaipa Companies, the private investment firm that is trying to acquire his former employer. The Times, which is owned by Tribune, said that Mr. Johnson will be a principal in the company, overseeing its media interests, including parts of Al Gore’s Current TV channel.

abstract: As rumors of a buyout dance around Dow Chemicals, the chemical giant is in talks with India’s Reliance Industries to create a joint venture that would reduce its exposure to the volatile commodity chemicals market. The Financial Times said that reports have suggested that a deal might lead to a takeover of Dow by Reliance, India’s largest public company, sending shares up 5 percent. But unnamed sources told the F.T. that such speculation was untrue.
lead_paragraph: As rumors of a buyout dance around Dow Chemicals, the chemical giant is in talks with India’s Reliance Industries to create a joint venture that would reduce its exposure to the volatile commodity chemicals market. abstract: The three-month war over Caremark Rx is over, and the pharmacy chain from Woonsocket, R.I. has won. Caremark said Friday morning that its shareholders approved a $26.5 billion offer by CVS, the nation’s largest drugstore chain, creating a new company with tremendous clout over drug prices.
lead_paragraph: The three-month war over Caremark Rx is over, and the pharmacy chain from Woonsocket, R.I. has won. Caremark said Friday morning that its shareholders approved a $26.5 billion offer by CVS, the nation’s largest drugstore chain, creating a new company with tremendous clout over drug prices.

headline.main: Caremark Says Shareholders Approve CVS Merger

abstract: Blackstone Group, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, is preparing for an initial public offering, though the decision to go public has not yet been made, a person briefed on the plans told DealBook. CNBC’s David Faber, who originally reported the I.P.O. preparations Friday morning, said Blackstone has been working with investment bank Goldman Sachs on an offering, adding that preliminary prospectus could be filed with regulators in two weeks. An I.P.O. would be just the latest audacious move for Blackstone chairman Stephen Schwarzman, who recently led his firm in a $39 billion purchase of Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest leveraged buyout ever completed. It would also represent a remarkable turn for Mr. Schwarzman, who, in his role as buyout king, has extolled the virtues of leaving public shareholders behind.
lead_paragraph: Blackstone Group, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, is preparing for an initial public offering, though the decision to go public has not yet been made, a person briefed on the plans told DealBook. It would also represent a remarkable turn for Mr. Schwarzman, who, in his role as buyout king, has extolled the virtues of leaving public shareholders behind.

headline.main: Blackstone Said to Prepare for I.P.O.

abstract: As reports emerge that buyout behemoth  Blackstone Group is considering an initial public offering, here is the multibillion-dollar question: What would a publicly traded Blackstone be worth? But a comparison with Fortress Investment Group, which recently opened its kimono as part of its highly successful I.P.O., gives some extremely rough guideposts.

Kennedy, was referring to the Adagietto movement from Mahler’s Fifth Symphony; Mrs. Kennedy did not thank him in the letter for conducting “Mahler’s Requiem.” (Mahler never composed a requiem.).

abstract: A business partner of Conrad M. Black and three companies will pay $63.4 million to settle claims and debt with the Sun-Times Media Group, the company said Sunday. Mr. Black’s partner, F. David Radler, 64, was president and chief operating officer of the Sun-Times Group when it was known as Hollinger International. The payment means that Mr. Radler and firms he controls have paid a total of $72 million to settle claims and debt owed to the publisher, the Sun-Times Group, based in Chicago, said Sunday in a statement.

abstract: Walt Disney, concluding an internal investigation, cleared Steven P. Jobs on Friday of any misconduct in issuing backdated stock options at Pixar, the computer animation studio that Disney bought last year. A brief statement by John E. Pepper Jr., Disney’s chairman, did not mention Mr. Jobs by name. But the statement said that “while options were backdated at Pixar prior to the acquisition, no one currently associated” with Disney was involved in “any intentional or deliberate acts of misconduct.”

abstract: Once the center of power, the desk of Enron‘s former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, is up for sale on eBay. The desk is being sold by a charity, Saving Animals Across Borders, which is also auctioning the desks that Jeffrey Skilling and Richard Kinder used when they were presidents of the now-defunct energy company. Mr. Lay and Mr. Skilling, who also served as chief executive, were convicted in May 2006 for their role in the accounting fraud that led to the collapse of Enron in 2001.

abstract: Hercules Offshore, an oil and gas drilling company, said Monday that it would acquire a larger rival, Todco, for about $2.3 billion in cash and stock, gaining a larger footprint in the global oil rig market. Under the terms of the deal, Todco shareholders will receive .979 Hercules shares and $16 in cash for each of their shares, for a total of $42.01 per Todco share. The deal represents a 28 percent premium to Todco’s closing price Friday.

abstract: A budget released by the minority Conservative government on Monday would phase out special tax concessions for investors in oil sands projects by 2015. The current system dates back to 1972 and allows oil companies to depreciate capital investments in oil sands operations at a highly accelerated rate. Intended as a method of promoting oil sands developments, it effectively postpones all taxation on income from the projects until their billions of dollars in investment costs are fully written down. The left-leaning New Democrat Party has said that the current rush to develop the oil sands makes special tax concessions unnecessary.

abstract: China Mobile Communications invited bids for contracts worth as much as 24 billion yuan ($3.1 billion) to build the country’s first high-speed phone network. The company asked equipment makers to submit bids for the network, based on a homegrown standard, said Chen Haofei, the secretary general of an industry group backing the standard. China Mobile, based in Beijing, will spend 4 billion yuan on subsidies for third-generation handsets, and the network will cover eight cities in China, including Beijing and Shanghai.

abstract: Companies are expected to spend more on mobile technology and business travel.
snippet: Companies are expected to spend more on mobile technology and business travel.
lead_paragraph: Work harder, and watch your spending on the road. That’s the message from financial executives at midsize companies surveyed by American Express and CFO Research Services. More than 40 percent of 300 executives said they expected to increase spending on mobile technology “designed to increase business travelers’ productivity” like cellphones, personal digital assistants and laptops, said American Express, which offers business travel management services, including corporate credit cards. Nearly three-quarters said they planned to improve procedures for making sure employees complied with travel spending policies to “spot and halt maverick spending by employees,” said Tom Tierney, the senior vice president for sales at the American Express U.S. Commercial Card division.

headline.main: More Mobile Technology

The parent of the Chicago exchange said Monday that its board had authorized talks with ICE, adding it had not changed a recommendation that shareholders vote next month in favor of a merger struck with CME Holdings, parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
lead_paragraph: CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Bord of Trade, and IntercontinentalExchange, the energy derivatives market, are moving quickly after a proposal on Thursday by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion. The parent of the Chicago exchange said Monday that its board had authorized talks with ICE, adding it had not changed a recommendation that shareholders vote next month in favor of a merger struck with CME Holdings, parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

headline.main: CBOT Green Lights Talks With ICE

abstract: The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday. Mr. Lewis, 59, received $1.5 million in salary, $6.5 million in nonequity incentive plan compensation, and stock and option awards that were valued by the company at $14.6 million on the dates they were issued.
lead_paragraph: The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday. headline.main: At Bank of America, $23 Million for Chief

abstract: The former head of Citibank‘s worldwide commodities trading desk was sentenced to 15 months in prison Monday after pleading guilty to conspiracy last year in connection with a plan to inflate trading profits by as much as $20 million. At a hearing in Manhattan, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court also ordered the former trader, David Becker, to pay $200,000 in restitution and a $25,000 fine. The prison term will be followed by two years of supervised release.

The prison term will be followed by two years of supervised release.

headline.main: Sentence for a Former Citibank Trader

abstract: The American Medical Association asked the Justice Department on Monday to block the UnitedHealth Group‘s proposed $2.6 billion purchase of Sierra Health Services, saying the deal would be anticompetitive. The A.M.A. estimated that if the merger were completed, UnitedHealth would control 78 percent of the market for health maintenance organizations in Nevada and 95 percent of the market in the Las Vegas-Paradise area.

abstract: Jury selection began on Monday in the $101 million insider trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, who watched prospective jurors and actively consulted with lawyers.

abstract: Quanta Services, a builder of energy and telecommunications networks based in Houston, said Monday that it would buy InfraSource Services for $1.26 billion to expand its services and increase its national presence. The all-stock deal calls for the exchange of 1.223 shares of Quanta’s common stock for each outstanding common share of InfraSource. That is about $30.13 a share, a 17.4 percent premium over the closing price of InfraSource stock last Friday, according to the companies.

That is about $30.13 a share, a 17.4 percent premium over the closing price of InfraSource stock last Friday, according to the companies.

headline.main: Quanta Services to Buy InfraSource

abstract: Joining a growing chorus from American businesses, more than 50 major investors, who together manage $4 trillion, asked Congress on Monday to enact tough federal legislation to curb carbon emissions and to overhaul energy policies nationwide. It marks the first time that a group of major money managers, including Merrill Lynch and the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, have requested that Congress take such extensive action on global warming.
lead_paragraph: Joining a growing chorus from American businesses, more than 50 major investors, who together manage $4 trillion, asked Congress on Monday to enact tough federal legislation to curb carbon emissions and to overhaul energy policies nationwide. headline.main: Big Investors Take Their Climate Concerns To Congress

abstract: Rosneft, Russia’s state-run oil company, will borrow $22 billion to buy assets, including those of bankrupt Yukos Oil, helping President Vladimir Putin seal control of the nation’s energy industry. Rosneft’s board on March 15 approved borrowing $13 billion and $9 billion in credits arranged by banks including Goldman Sachs and BNP Paribas, the company said in a statement Tuesday.

abstract: Bear Stearns and China’s richest man, Huang Guangyu, set up a $500 million fund to invest in retailers in China. Mr. Guangyu, chairman of Gome Electrical Appliances Holdings, will use his closely held Eagle Investment Group to invest $250 million for buying non-appliance retailers, with the New York-based investment bank contributing the remainder, the companies said in a joint statement Tuesday.

abstract: Investors were flush with love for Intarcia Therapeutics, despite a failed initial public offering in 2005 and abandonment of its lead-drug program a year ago. The 10-year-old drug developer returned to the well to raise $50 million in a venture capital round led by new investor New Leaf Venture Partners to advance drug delivery programs for hepatitis and diabetes.

abstract: BlackRock has added its name to the list of those opposing the $60.50 per share, $3.1 billion buyout of Laureate Education. But the go-shop window has closed without a better offer. BlackRock sent a letter Monday to the Laureate independent board members stating that without an increase it would not support the management buyout backed by a consortium including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Citigroup Private Equity and SAC Capital Management.

abstract: The production company Nu Image/ Millennium Films is reportedly in talks to buy the hedge-fund backed First Look Pictures, whose chief executive and largest shareholder, Henry Winterstern, recently resigned. The move is an about face since Mr. Wintersten was himself planning to make a run at Nu Image before he fell afoul of a backer Prentice Capital Management, reportedly for his lavish spending habits and inability to pick a winner.

abstract: China’s securities regulator barred companies from using proceeds from share sales to invest in stocks in an attempt to damp overheating financial markets. Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said Tuesday.

Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said Tuesday.

headline.main: Chinese Regulators Move to Cool Market

abstract: Landry’s Restaurant Group, which is battling Patina Restaurant Group for control for Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, is claiming that Wollensky’s chief executive, Alan Stillman, is pushing the Patina deal because he stands to personally gain if the Los Angeles group walks away the winner.
lead_paragraph: Landry’s Restaurant Group, which is battling Patina Restaurant Group for control for Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, is claiming that Wollensky’s chief executive, Alan Stillman, is pushing the Patina deal because he stands to personally gain if the Los Angeles group walks away the winner.

abstract: After Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game publisher announced Monday that it was mulling a sale, analysts appeared divided on whether the company could pull off a deal, and if so, with whom. Take-Two said that it was weighing options including a possible sale of the company, days after a group of private equity and mutual funds that control 46 percent of the outstanding shares said it would seek to oust the board and possibly the top management.

abstract: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise is nearing a deal to buy a series of aviation businesses from the Carlyle Group for more than $1.5 billion, Reuters reported Monday, citing an unnamed source. As part of the agreement, DAE, an investment firm, would buy Landmark Aviation, an aircraft maintenance provider, and Standard Aero, which provides repair and overhaul services at airport terminals for small-jet aviation and some military transports, according to Reuters’ source.

abstract: Palm, the iconic but struggling maker of smartphones and handheld devices, could reach a deal to sell itself by this Thursday for at least $20 a share, the Web site Unstrung reported citing unnamed sources. Among the four leading bidders is Nokia, the world’s largest cellphone maker, according to the site. But Unstrung reported that Palm management would prefer a private equity bidder, naming the Texas Pacific Group and, tentatively, Silver Lake Partners as in the running.

headline.main: Palm May Reach Deal by Thursday, Report Says

abstract: Affiliated Computer Services‘s chairman, Darwin Deason, and Cerberus Capital Management said Tuesday they had offered to take the technology outsourcing company private for $59.25 a share in cash, or about $8.2 billion including assumed debt. The offer represents a 15.5 percent premium to Affiliated Computer’s closing share price Monday.
lead_paragraph: Affiliated Computer Services‘s chairman, Darwin Deason, and Cerberus Capital Management said Tuesday they had offered to take the technology outsourcing company private for $59.25 a share in cash, or about $8.2 billion including assumed debt. headline.main: Affiliated Computer Gets Buyout Offer

abstract: “Mad Money” host Jim Cramer has gained a huge following, and more than a few critics as well, with his explosive stock-picking patter. But in a revealing video interview with TheStreet.com, the financial Web site he cofounded, Mr. Cramer drops some bombshells that go well beyond his usual chair-throwing, ‘Booyah’-shouting routine. In the clip, which has drawn lots of commentary on YouTube, Mr. Cramer brags about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market and offers what amounts to a how-to to aspiring stock manipulators, The New York Post reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: “Mad Money” host Jim Cramer has gained a huge following, and more than a few critics as well, with his explosive stock-picking patter. In the clip, which has drawn lots of commentary on YouTube, Mr. Cramer brags about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market and offers what amounts to a how-to to aspiring stock manipulators, The New York Post reported Tuesday.

headline.main: Jim Cramer’s Guide to Market Manipulation

abstract: After 10 years, Blockbuster is running the closing credits on chief executive John Antioco. The video-rental chain, which has struggled to compete with changing movie-viewing habits and upstart services such as Netflix, said Tuesday that Mr. Antioco, who has led the company since 1997, would step down by the end of the year. The agreement drew praise from activist investor Carl Icahn, who sits on Blockbuster’s board. In previous years, Mr. Icahn has sparred with Mr. Antioco about how to run the company and how much Mr. Antioco gets paid.
lead_paragraph: After 10 years, Blockbuster is running the closing credits on chief executive John Antioco. The video-rental chain, which has struggled to compete with changing movie-viewing habits and upstart services such as Netflix, said Tuesday that Mr. Antioco, who has led the company since 1997, would step down by the end of the year. The agreement drew praise from activist investor Carl Icahn, who sits on Blockbuster’s board. In previous years, Mr. Icahn has sparred with Mr. Antioco about how to run the company and how much Mr. Antioco gets paid.

headline.main: Blockbuster Chief to Resign This Year

abstract: After a nearly four-month auction that sparked little excitement, Claire’s Stores may have finally found a bidder. The New York Post reported Tuesday that Apollo Management, the buyout firm run by Leon Black, is close to signing a $3 billion deal for the company, which sells jewelry and accessories to preteens. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Apollo would pay between $32 and $34.50 a share. Shares in the chain were up 1.33 percent at $31.17 in mid-morning trading Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After a nearly four-month auction that sparked little excitement, Claire’s Stores may have finally found a bidder. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Apollo would pay between $32 and $34.50 a share. Shares in the chain were up 1.33 percent at $31.17 in mid-morning trading Tuesday.

headline.main: Apollo to Buy Claire’s Stores for $3 Billion, Report Says

The move suggests that Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture firm that just celebrated the sale of portfolio company Tellme Networks to Microsoft, will be considering more investments in gaming startups.

abstract: Some harsh words, including the F-bomb, livened up the usually bland world of regulatory filings last week. The colorful exchange, noted by Paul Kedrosky on his blog Infectious Greed, was directed at Robert Chapman, the chief of Chapman Capital, whose grandiloquently harsh criticism of the companies he invests in regularly raises executive ire. (DealBook readers may recall that Mr. Chapman recently complained about not receiving a return phone call from the chief executive of eSpeed, another company he has pressured for change.)

abstract: It seems that the official talks between Barclays of Britain and ABN Amro of the Netherlands have been fruitful: The two have already hashed out agreements over location and management structure. In a statement, the two banks said that they have agreed to keep their headquarters in Amsterdam, and will maintain a primary listing on the London Stock Exchange and a secondary listing in Amsterdam.

abstract: With a Darwin Deason as an ally, Cerberus Capital Management might seem to have the buyout of Affiliated Computer Services all wrapped up. After all, Mr. Deason is Affiliated Computer’s founder and chairman, and he has a voting stake of nearly 42 percent in the company, a provider of technology outsourcing services. But after Mr. Deason and Cerberus announced their plan Tuesday to take the company private in a deal valued at $8.2 billion, including debt, Bryan Keane, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group, speculated that Mr. Deason might be open to teaming up with someone else.

abstract: Halcyon Asset Management, a hedge fund that manages $10 billion in assets, said Tuesday it hired Kyle Ransford as a managing principal to expand its real-estate investment activities. Mr. Ransford is a co-founder of Cardinal Real Estate Investments, a firm whose holdings include commercial and residential properties in New York and Los Angeles and islands in Fiji, according to its Web site. Mr. Ransford will remain a general partner at Cardinal, Halcyon said.

Mr. Ransford will remain a general partner at Cardinal, Halcyon said.

abstract: Sanford I. Weill’s reign as the banking industry’s top deal-maker may be coming to an end. If Barclays and ABN Amro succeed in their merger talks — they announced further progress Tuesday, including agreements on location and management structure — the deal would likely carry a price of more than $80 billion, which would surpass the value of Travelers’ landmark merger with Citicorp in 1998. That transaction is widely seen as the defining moment of Mr. Weill’s career and, up until now, no bank deal has topped its $72.6 billion price tag.
lead_paragraph: Sanford I. Weill’s reign as the banking industry’s top deal-maker may be coming to an end. That transaction is widely seen as the defining moment of Mr. Weill’s career and, up until now, no bank deal has topped its $72.6 billion price tag.

headline.main: A Bank Merger for the Record Books

abstract: It’s official: Claire’s Stores, purveyor of costume jewelry and accessories to preteens, said Tuesday afternoon that it will be acquired by Apollo Management for about $3.1 billion in cash. Under the terms of the deal, Apollo will pay $33 a share for the company, a premium over Monday’s closing price of $30.76.
lead_paragraph: It’s official: Claire’s Stores, purveyor of costume jewelry and accessories to preteens, said Tuesday afternoon that it will be acquired by Apollo Management for about $3.1 billion in cash. headline.main: Apollo Signs $3.1 Billion Deal to Buy Claire’s

abstract: Faster than a thumb-typing Treo addict, rumors about a Palm takeover were flying Tuesday. The chatter, which began earlier in the day with a report on the Web site Unstrung.com, grew louder after blogs and news reports started seeing a potential connection between the purported Palm auction and the decision by Motorola chief executive Edward Zander to cancel a speech at a major industry conference next week. A Motorola spokesman told the Chicago Tribune the cancellation was because of “an unforeseen scheduling conflict,” but there was speculation that Mr. Zander might be too busy negotiating a bid for Palm.

abstract: The United States will make a final attempt at clearing barriers to trade in automobiles, medicines and rice as part of a free-trade agreement with South Korea by sending a trade official to Seoul next week. Deputy Trade Representative Karan Bhatia, who will make the trip, said it is the last chance to get a pact. American and Korean negotiators must reach an accord this month to get it to their legislatures before President George Bush’s “fast-track” trade negotiating authority ends July 1. An agreement would be the largest American trade deal since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994.

abstract: The Delphi Corporation, the auto parts maker, said it had filed for bankruptcy protection for a Spanish unit as part of a plan to close a money-losing plant in Cadiz, Spain. The parts maker will spend about $70 million this quarter for severance costs for the 1,570 workers at the plant, which makes steering mechanisms. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., disclosed the measure in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has not yet reached a severance agreement with the Spanish union. The Cadiz plant is the primary asset of Delphi Automotive Systems España, Delphi said.

abstract: The main French business federation said that the French economy would be unable to grow at its full capacity under programs put forth by the existing candidates for president and announced an economic program of its own. The federation, Medef, called for looser labor rules, lower taxes and incentives to bolster investment and innovation. Laurence Parisot, left, president of Medef, said there was little hope of achieving what she called “an ambitious but realistic goal” with the platforms of the three leading presidential candidates: Nicolas Sarkozy, Ségolène Royal and François Bayrou. “If you look at the three principal programs, none of them is proposing what we believe is right,” she said at a news conference. The first round of voting in the election is scheduled for April 22 with a runoff set for May 6.

lead_paragraph: Later this year, the National Film Preservation Foundation is going to re-release a silent movie from 1912 called “The Usurer’s Grip.” It’s a cautionary tale about borrowed money that revolves around the Jenkses, a fictional middle-class family who need a $25 loan so their young daughter can be treated for consumption. After a loan shark tricks Mr. Jenks into borrowing at an interest rate of 180 percent, the family is brought to the brink of ruin.

abstract: Toshiba and Hynix Semiconductor agreed to end patent disputes over flash memory chips used to store data in electronic devices like digital cameras and MP3 players. Financial terms were not disclosed. Each company will get a license to the other’s semiconductor technology and signed product supply agreements. The accord settles all patent-related litigation in Japan and the United States, including three disputes before the International Trade Commission in Washington. The legal battles between the companies began in November 2004 when Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, sued Hynix, based in Ichon, South Korea, after the companies failed to extend a licensing agreement.

abstract: Top executives from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and tje Texas Pacific Group on Tuesday urged Texas legislators not to create new regulatory hurdles to their $45 billion purchase of the electric utility TXU. According to the Associated Press, Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis suggested the private equity firms might walk away from the deal, which would be the largest leveraged buyout ever, if such measures were passed. But the Dallas Morning News said the investors “stopped short” of suggesting new regulations could kill the deal.

abstract: A new report published by the National Venture Capital Association says that companies backed by venture capital providers over the past three decades employed nearly a 10th of private-sector workers and generally outperformed their non-venture-funded counterparts in 2005. The study, conducted by Global Insight, said that American companies that received venture capital funding from 1970 to 2005 accounted for 10 million jobs in 2005, or 9 percent of private-sector positions, $2.1 trillion in revenues, and 16.6 percent of total gross domestic production.
lead_paragraph: A new report published by the National Venture Capital Association says that companies backed by venture capital providers over the past three decades employed nearly a 10th of private-sector workers and generally outperformed their non-venture-funded counterparts in 2005. abstract: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new “period of restrained growth” for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.
