abstract: On Tuesday, Reuters reported unusual trading activity related to agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland, which some traders chalked up to rumors of a possible takeover, either by another company or by a private equity firm. The speculation drew out some skeptics, including a Merrill Lynch analyst who called a leveraged buyout of the company “unlikely” and an unnamed options trader who dismissed the chatter to Reuters as the “latest of a long series of recent rumors in all kinds of stocks.”
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Reuters reported unusual trading activity related to agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland, which some traders chalked up to rumors of a possible takeover, either by another company or by a private equity firm. The speculation drew out some skeptics, including a Merrill Lynch analyst who called a leveraged buyout of the company “unlikely” and an unnamed options trader who dismissed the chatter to Reuters as the “latest of a long series of recent rumors in all kinds of stocks.”

headline.main: More Doubts on A.D.M. Buyout Chatter

abstract: Amaranth Advisors, which managed $9 billion in assets before imploding after its energy-market trades went bad, is the best-known hedge fund casualty of 2006. But there were lots of others: At least 83 of these private investment pools gave up the ghost, according to a survey by the industry publication Absolute Return. Many of these were small funds, but nine (including Amaranth) had assets of at least $1 billion before calling it quits. That is a sharp contrast from 2005, when no billion-plus funds folded.

abstract: CNBC was reporting Wednesday afternoon that a “major Palm shareholder” expects cellphone giant Motorola to announce a deal to acquire the company for about $2 billion. The announcement could come as soon as Thursday, the unidentified shareholder said. Rumors about such a deal made the rounds Tuesday after the Web site Unstrung.com reported that four parties — Motorola, cellphone company Nokia and private equity firms Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group — were considering a bid for Palm. None of those firms, nor Motorola, have commented on the deal speculation.

abstract: Bruce Wasserstein, the veteran deal maker and head of investment bank Lazard, could be getting out of the legal publishing business. Mr. Wasserstein’s investment firm, Wasserstein & Company, said Wednesday that it hired Credit Suisse to consider strategic options for portfolio company ALM, including a possible sale. ALM publishes 34 magazines and newspapers, including American Lawyer and the National Law Journal. The decision to seek out potential buyers came about 10 years after Mr. Wasserstein’s firm acquired ALM through its U.S. Equity Partners fund.

abstract: Middlemen and marketing costs have long been viewed with suspicion by critics of commerce. But these practices are usually signs of market sophistication, not waste.
snippet: Middlemen and marketing costs have long been viewed with suspicion by critics of commerce. But these practices are usually signs of market sophistication, not waste.
lead_paragraph: Proponents of single-payer national health insurance note that private health insurance has overhead costs of 10 to 25 percent of expenditures. Medicare, by contrast, has overhead costs of about 2 to 3 percent, and socialized European health care systems generally have low overhead costs as well. That is why single-payer supporters claim that we can save money by substituting government for private insurance. But this would shift overhead costs, not reduce them.

headline.main: Abolishing the Middlemen Won’t Make Health Care a Free Lunch

abstract: Japan’s trade surplus unexpectedly widened in February after a decline in oil prices caused import growth to slow. Export growth slowed. The entire Lunar New Year holiday fell in February, cutting short the time companies could ship goods to markets that observe the holiday, and the economist Noriaki Haseyama said it was too early to determine if exports are stalling.

abstract: South Korea’s economy expanded 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter, more than first estimated, as exports declined less than initially anticipated, the Bank of Korea said. The figure was revised from an initial estimate of 0.8 percent and was down from a revised 1.2 percent rate in the third quarter. Goods exports fell 0.5 percent, less than the initial estimate of a 1 percent decline, the report showed. It was the first quarterly drop in exports since the three months ended Sept. 30, 2004. Business investment rose 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months and construction climbed 0.6 percent in the quarter. Private spending advanced 1 percent in the quarter, compared with an earlier estimate of a 0.8 percent increase, the report showed.

Mack, the investment bank’s chief executive.

abstract: Rock stars and media giants are not the only ones worried about their creations being given away for free on the Web. Merrill Lynch, the giant securities firm, is taking new steps to protect its stock research, which it described in a note to clients as being “Napster-ized” — a reference to the Web site that used to be a hotbed of wanton song-swapping before it went bankrupt and relaunched as a subscription-based service. In Thursday’s letter, Candace Browning, Merrill’s chief of global securities research and economics, began with an anecdote about how Merrill’s research had recently been duplicated “with plagiaristic precision” on a Web site based in New Jersey. Now, she wrote, the firm is taking stronger measures to safeguard its analysis.

abstract: The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced Thursday that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent. The new dividend – 23 cents a share a quarter, up from 17.5 cents – is payable on June 13 to shareholders of record on June 1.

abstract: India’s drive to become a global economic powerhouse faces a huge roadblock in its inefficient, largely state-controlled financial system, The New York Times reports. Two-thirds of India’s banking business is conducted through less than 5 percent of its branches, and its growing corporate sector has headed overseas for financial advice and loans.

Greylock Partners and Redpoint Ventures, both of which gave money in the company’s previous funding round, also contributed to the new round.

abstract: Japanese pharmaceutical titan Eisai said Thursday it will bulk up its cancer drug pipeline with a deal to buy Morphotek for $325 million. The move will expand Eisai’s presence in the United States. It will also bring the traditional pharmaceutical company deeper into the biologic therapeutics field, where products are generally made using living cells. Venture-capital backed Morphotek develops monoclonal antibodies for the treatment of cancer, inflammation, and infectious diseases.

abstract: After several rounds of negotiations, General Electric said Friday that it will buy Sanyo Electric Credit, the financing affiliate of struggling electronics maker Sanyo, in a transaction that could top out at 135 billion yen ($1.14 billion). In a statement Friday, Tokyo-listed Sanyo Electric Credit said the company had agreed to a tender offer from General Electric under which the U.S. conglomerate will pay 3,250 yen ($27.51) per share, a premium of nearly 62 percent from the closing price of 2,010 yen ($17.02) on Friday.

abstract: Though Barclays‘ negotiations with Dutch rival ABN Amro are exclusive right now, another bidder may want to bust in. abstract: By lifting restrictions on air traffic between the United States and Europe, the so-called “open skies” agreement that European Union officials approved on Thursday may herald a renewed push for airline consolidation. Under the accord, European and American airlines will be allowed to fly any route between any European city and one in the United States. The change, which will take effect in March 2008, is expected to markedly increase competition in many European countries.

abstract: Blackstone Group, confirming a firestorm of speculation, said Thursday it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion. The preliminary prospectus offered a first glimpse inside Blackstone’s closely guarded money machine, which churned out $2.3 billion in profit in 2006. The offering is being structured to allow Blackstone to retain many advantages of a private business — a setup that Breakingviews compares with Berkshire Hathaway under Warren Buffett.

abstract: Are private equity deals getting too expensive? A reader of the Financial Times’s Web site posed that timely question to Philip Purcell, the former chief executive of Morgan Stanley. His answer was a definite maybe. Mr. Purcell, who is now the president of Continental Investors, replied that prices are high enough that some buyout firms might see lower returns on current deals than they saw over the past 15 years. “History would say that some buyers are overpaying,” he said during an online Q&A.

abstract: Though it briefly reigned last year as the largest leveraged buyout ever, the $33 billion deal to take HCA private almost ended with a drink and a shrug. lead_paragraph: CONRAD, Mont. — Mary Rose Derks was a 65-year-old widow in 1990, when she began preparing for the day she could no longer care for herself. The companies were announcing a new joint venture for Internet video.

abstract: The Internet start-up Livedoor was ordered to pay a $2.4 million fine Friday – the largest in Japanese corporate history – for violating securities laws. The fine is the latest blow in a scandal that has led to convictions of seven former executives and accountants. The Tokyo District Court ordered Livedoor to pay the fine – 280 million yen – and its subsidiary Livedoor Marketing to pay $338,000, a court official said on the customary condition of anonymity.

headline.main: Livedoor Given Japan’s Largest Corporate Fine

abstract: As takeover rumors swirl around Palm, the maker of the Treo smartphone, technology analysis firm The 451 Group assesses the fit — or lack thereof — for a half-dozen potential acquirers, including Dell and Hewlett-Packard. The report calls a deal with Research in Motion, which makes the Blackberry handheld device, a “very intriguing possibility.” Such a combination could allow Research in Motion to build a line of Windows devices that are still true BlackBerrys with relatively little effort, The 451 Group writes.

It will have annual revenues of 6.7 billion pounds ($13.1 billion), and an estimated market capitalization of 5 billion pounds ($9.8 billion).

Eight of the nine justices will hear the oral argument in Glen Billing v. Credit Suisse First Boston, a class action that asks what role, if any, antitrust law should play in the regulation of the securities industry, and specifically in policing I.P.O.’s.

abstract: The auction for a prized swath of spectrum that could reshape the debate over who controls access to the networks that deliver digital content to consumers is about to go into high gear. Among those maneuvering ahead of the auction for the spectrum, which could be used for voice services for cellular carriers, new frequencies for emergency responders, or a commercial high-speed broadband multimedia network, are the nation’s four largest cellular providers, rural and regional wireless carriers, cable and satellite television companies and a range of technology companies – including Google and Yahoo.

headline.main: Hot Spectrum Draws Cash, and Ideals

abstract: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, and Acciona said they will offer at least 41 euros ($54.37) a share for the stock they don’t already own of Spanish power company Endesa, trumping a rival bid by E.On. The offer depends on E.On receiving less than 50 percent of Endesa in its tender, Acciona said in a statement Monday. The bid by Enel and Acciona, which together control 46 percent of Endesa, values all of Spain’s largest power utility at a minimum of 43.4 billion euros.
lead_paragraph: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, and Acciona said they will offer at least 41 euros ($54.37) a share for the stock they don’t already own of Spanish power company Endesa, trumping a rival bid by E.On. abstract: Even with their record bonuses last year, Wall Streeters may have reasons to envy their counterparts in the Old Country. Bloomberg News reports that traders in London are making as much as 50 percent more in compensation than traders in New York, according to a study by Napier Scott Executive Search (a firm which just happens to be based in London). The report comes as New York is engaged some deep soul-searching about whether it is losing its edge to London as a venue for initial public offerings, hedge funds and other badges of status in the financial-services industry.

abstract: TRAVEL COST MORE IN 2006 Average one-way domestic air fares paid by corporations, which dropped to a six-year low in 2005, rose last year to $231, the American Express Business Travel Monitor reported. Average one-way international fares continued a four-year climb, to $1,707, and average international daily hotel rates rose for the fifth consecutive year, to $230. Average daily car rental rates crept up again, to $69. Corporate pressure on business travelers to comply with booking policies held down the rate of increases, said Mike Streit, vice president of American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. The average air fare rates were calculated from hundreds of domestic and international routes negotiated for corporate clients by American Express, from discount coach to first class. The average rate for car rentals includes fuel, taxes and other charges. Among domestic hotels, average nightly rates rose most sharply in the cheapest niche, the budget category, to $179 in the fourth quarter of 2006 from $150 in the comparable 2005 quarter.

Average daily car rental rates crept up again, to $69. Corporate pressure on business travelers to comply with booking policies held down the rate of increases, said Mike Streit, vice president of American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. The average air fare rates were calculated from hundreds of domestic and international routes negotiated for corporate clients by American Express, from discount coach to first class. The average rate for car rentals includes fuel, taxes and other charges. Among domestic hotels, average nightly rates rose most sharply in the cheapest niche, the budget category, to $179 in the fourth quarter of 2006 from $150 in the comparable 2005 quarter.

abstract: Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the company’s share price yesterday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefour’s largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company. Speculation that a takeover was imminent had swirled around the company since last month when Colony Capital and Mr. Arnault, together with a hedge fund, bought a 9.8 percent stake. Stock in Carrefour, which is based in Paris, fell 1.19 euros, or 2 percent, to 54.22 euros a share.

abstract: Credit Suisse Group said it paid its chairman, Walter Kielholz, 16 million Swiss francs ($13.2 million) last year, one-third more than a year earlier, after profit at the bank, the second-largest in Switzerland, rose to a record. Mr. Kielholz, who earned 12 million francs in 2005, received 9 million francs in cash and 7 million francs in share-based compensation, the bank said in its 2006 annual report, published Monday. Marcel Ospel, chairman of larger Swiss rival UBS AG, received 26.6 million francs.

abstract: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

abstract: Gildan Activewear, one of the largest makers of T-shirts in North America, said it would close five plants in Canada, the United States and Mexico and eliminate 1,830 jobs to move production to lower-cost operations in Central America. The company will shut two textile plants in Montreal, two sewing plants in Mexico and a cutting factory in Bombay, N.Y., it said. Gildan will record a restructuring charge of $21.5 million, or 35 cents a share, in fiscal 2007, which ends in September. Gildan, based in Montreal, is shifting production from older plants in North America to newer factories in Central America. It expects to save $45 million a year starting in fiscal 2008 from lower expenses for production, shipping and duties.

abstract: DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.
lead_paragraph: DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.

headline.main: DoubleClick Said to Consider Sale

abstract: Arguments were laid out before the Supreme Court on Tuesday regarding whether the securities industry can be sued for allegations of antitrust violations in creating syndicates for initial public offerings. The court justices challenged the three lawyers who appeared before them by drilling down on the question of whether the Securities and Exchange Commission adequately polices the securities industry.
lead_paragraph: Arguments were laid out before the Supreme Court on Tuesday regarding whether the securities industry can be sued for allegations of antitrust violations in creating syndicates for initial public offerings. The court justices challenged the three lawyers who appeared before them by drilling down on the question of whether the Securities and Exchange Commission adequately polices the securities industry.

headline.main: Supreme Court Hears I.P.O. Arguments

abstract: Wireless local-area-network technology developer Aruba Networks generated about $88 million in its first day of trading on Nasdaq Tuesday. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is one of a crop of venture capital-backed compaines to have done well in March I.P.O.s. Others include Glu Mobile and Sourcefire even though none of them has shown a profit. Still, Aruba is growing. Its revenue rose to $72.5 million last year from $12 million in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Wireless local-area-network technology developer Aruba Networks generated about $88 million in its first day of trading on Nasdaq Tuesday. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is one of a crop of venture capital-backed compaines to have done well in March I.P.O.s. Others include Glu Mobile and Sourcefire even though none of them has shown a profit. Still, Aruba is growing. Its revenue rose to $72.5 million last year from $12 million in 2005.

headline.main: Aruba Raises $88 Million in I.P.O.

abstract: A nutritional supplement company, NBTY, is up for sale, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. The company’s market capitalization is $3.3 billion based on Tuesday’s trading. Bear Stearns and Bank of America are advising NBTY and first-round bids are expected in the next few weeks.
lead_paragraph: A nutritional supplement company, NBTY, is up for sale, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. The company’s market capitalization is $3.3 billion based on Tuesday’s trading. Bear Stearns and Bank of America are advising NBTY and first-round bids are expected in the next few weeks.

headline.main: Vitamin Maker NBTY Said to Seek a Buyer

abstract: Riviera Holdings, the owner of the Riviera Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and the Riviera Black Hawk Casino in Black Hawk, Colo., is once again fielding a buyout offer from Riv Acquisition Holdings. The bidding group, which includes Starwood Capital‘s chief executive, Barry Sternlicht, said Monday it had offered $27 a share in cash for Riviera. A deal could be valued at $551.5 million. Shareholders in Riviera, which is based in Las Vegas, turned down a previous offer in 2006.

Shareholders in Riviera, which is based in Las Vegas, turned down a previous offer in 2006.

headline.main: Bidders Roll the Dice Again on Riviera Holdings

abstract: Venture funding in San Jose, Calif., during 2006 totaled about $616.4 million, up 27.4 percent from the previous year, according to a report released Monday. The report, from VentureDeal and the Business Performance Management Forum, said San Jose’s venture financing growth was more than double the national average.

abstract: City National, a financial management company based in Los Angeles, said it had agreed to buy Lydian Wealth Management, an asset manager, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline.main: City National to Buy Lydian Wealth

abstract: General Motors will not make a bid for DaimlerChrysler‘s Chrysler unit, the Times of London reported, citing unnamed sources close to the talks. The report came after an analyst at Bear Stearns, quoted in the The Detroit Free Press, suggested that a merger between General Motors and Chrysler “would be challenged to pass antitrust scrutiny.” Earlier in the week, the Detroit Free Press said that while General Motors held talks with DaimlerChrysler about a transaction in Janaury, it is not actively pursuing a purchase.
lead_paragraph: General Motors will not make a bid for DaimlerChrysler‘s Chrysler unit, the Times of London reported, citing unnamed sources close to the talks. The report came after an analyst at Bear Stearns, quoted in the The Detroit Free Press, suggested that a merger between General Motors and Chrysler “would be challenged to pass antitrust scrutiny.” Earlier in the week, the Detroit Free Press said that while General Motors held talks with DaimlerChrysler about a transaction in Janaury, it is not actively pursuing a purchase.

headline.main: G.M. Will Not Bid for Chrysler, Report Says

abstract: A Web-based software provider, Vocus, has announced a secondary public offering of up to 3.3 million shares that could generate a total of more than $67 million. By selling about 1.2 million shares of common stock at just over $20 a share, Vocus expects to generate $23.2 million directly, after deducting underwriting fees. Certain selling stockholders are selling an additional 1.6 million shares.
lead_paragraph: A Web-based software provider, Vocus, has announced a secondary public offering of up to 3.3 million shares that could generate a total of more than $67 million. By selling about 1.2 million shares of common stock at just over $20 a share, Vocus expects to generate $23.2 million directly, after deducting underwriting fees. Certain selling stockholders are selling an additional 1.6 million shares.

headline.main: Vocus Stock Sale Could Bring in $67 Million

abstract: The Swiss metal company Xstrata is facing pressure to increase its all-cash $4.6-billion bid for LionOre Mining International, a nickel mining company, following recommendations from analysts who said the offer undervalues LionOre. Xstrata proposed the deal on Monday, bidding $18.50 a share, but the offer was met with derision by institutional shareholders looking for more cash.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss metal company Xstrata is facing pressure to increase its all-cash $4.6-billion bid for LionOre Mining International, a nickel mining company, following recommendations from analysts who said the offer undervalues LionOre. Xstrata proposed the deal on Monday, bidding $18.50 a share, but the offer was met with derision by institutional shareholders looking for more cash.

headline.main: Xstrata Under Pressure to Increase LionOre Bid

abstract: Aerovance, a drug maker, said Tuesday that Clarus Ventures had agreed to provide $32 million of financing that will allow it to independently pursue a clinical trial of its asthma drug Aerovant later this year. Aerovance is continuing to seek partnerships with pharmaceutical companies in support of trials that would give the partner licensing rights to Aerovant. The new funding will give Aerovance more freedom to select a partner for the drug’s marketing and sales.

Aerovance is continuing to seek partnerships with pharmaceutical companies in support of trials that would give the partner licensing rights to Aerovant. The new funding will give Aerovance more freedom to select a partner for the drug’s marketing and sales.

headline.main: Aerovance Secures $32 Million V.C. Round

abstract: ATS Automation Tooling Systems said Tuesday it had cancalled an initial public offering of 250 million Canadian dollars ($216 million) for its solar cell unit, Photowatt Technologies. The offering was in the works for more than a year and was postponed two weeks ago. ATS said Tuesday that two Photowatt orders, valued at more than $6.2 million, had been delayed by customers.
lead_paragraph: ATS Automation Tooling Systems said Tuesday it had cancalled an initial public offering of 250 million Canadian dollars ($216 million) for its solar cell unit, Photowatt Technologies. The offering was in the works for more than a year and was postponed two weeks ago. ATS said Tuesday that two Photowatt orders, valued at more than $6.2 million, had been delayed by customers.

headline.main: ATS Calls Off I.P.O.

abstract: HSBC has hired a Credit Suisse banker, David Simons, as head of leveraged and acquisition finance in the Asia-Pacific region. Simons previously headed leveraged finance for non-Japan Asia at Credit Suisse. Mr. Simons will take up his new functions in May and will lead the bank’s efforts to build its strengths in event-driven investment grade and non-investment grade financing in Asia.

abstract: In the ongoing saga of the Tribune auction, real estate magnate Samuel Zell appears closer than ever to winning the day. Tribune is expected to name a victorious bidder at the end of this week and Mr. Zell’s $8 billion takeover offer is emerging as the most likely candidate, Bloomberg News said citing unnamed sources.

abstract: The president of the Japanese electronics giant Sanyo, Toshimasa Iue, is expected to resign early next week following a series of management failures and an accountancy scandal that has badly damaged the company’s image, the Times of London reported, citing sources it did not identify.

headline.main: Sanyo Chief Expected to Resign, Report Says

abstract: The Dutch banking giant ABN Amro said Wednesday that it would look for other possible deals should talks with Barclays fall through. ABN also urged shareholders to reject a motion to break up the company. While ABN said it was “excited” about a potential deal with Barclays, it is unclear whether talks will lead to a merger.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch banking giant ABN Amro said Wednesday that it would look for other possible deals should talks with Barclays fall through. abstract: With the floodgates of private equity cash securely open, investors are eyeing the full corporate landscape for buyout candidates. Based on a report from Goldman Sachs, BusinessWeek today wonders just who the next targets will be.

abstract: British Airways is considering a 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) bid for a rival British carrier, bmi, according to The Times of London. The paper said that bmi’s chairman, Michael Bishop, who is also a 50 percent shareholder, has received approaches from a number of airlines interested in buying a stake.
lead_paragraph: British Airways is considering a 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) bid for a rival British carrier, bmi, according to The Times of London. The paper said that bmi’s chairman, Michael Bishop, who is also a 50 percent shareholder, has received approaches from a number of airlines interested in buying a stake.

headline.main: BA Considers Bidding for a Rival

abstract: Bear Stearns said Tuesday it paid its chief executive, James Cayne, $40 million in cash, stock and other compensation last year, which was 32 percent more than in 2005. The Financial Times reported that Mr. Cayne’s compensation was on a par with the $40.5 million paid to Lehman Brothers‘ chief executive Richard Fuld, but less than what the chiefs of Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs earned last year. Financial News said Mr. Cayne received 24 percent of the money Bear Stearns set aside for the bonuses of its top five executives.
lead_paragraph: Bear Stearns said Tuesday it paid its chief executive, James Cayne, $40 million in cash, stock and other compensation last year, which was 32 percent more than in 2005. headline.main: Bear Stearns C.E.O. Earned $40 Million in 2006

abstract: Even as analysts speculate whether the Blackstone Group is trying to challenge Wall Street’s investment banks with its initial public offering, the biggest bank of them all is aggressively targeting private equity firms’ turf. Goldman Sachs chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, said Tuesday that his firm’s next buyout fund could reach $20 billion, which would be the largest such fund ever raised — by either a bank or a private equity firm. The remarks, which Mr. Blankfein made at his firm’s annual shareholder meeting, came as Blackstone is out raising a fund of its own that could end up a similar size.

The remarks, which Mr. Blankfein made at his firm’s annual shareholder meeting, came as Blackstone is out raising a fund of its own that could end up a similar size.

headline.main: Goldman Aims for $20 Billion Buyout Fund

abstract: AMSTERDAM, March 28 (Reuters) - The Dutch bank ABN AMRO (NYSE:ABN) on Wednesday urged shareholders to reject plans by a hedge fund to break-up or sell the company, as it pursues a merger with Britain's Barclays to create a bank worth over $175 billion.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM, March 28 (Reuters) - The Dutch bank ABN AMRO (NYSE:ABN) on Wednesday urged shareholders to reject plans by a hedge fund to break-up or sell the company, as it pursues a merger with Britain's Barclays to create a bank worth over $175 billion.

headline.main: ABN AMRO Urges Shareholders to Reject Breakup

abstract: BERLIN, March 28 (AP) -- German sports car maker Porsche AG said Wednesday it had completed its acquisition of more shares in Volkswagen AG, boosting its stake in Europe's biggest automaker to 30.94 percent and triggering a formal takeover offer to VW's shareholders. Porsche doesn't expect many VW shareholders will accept its below-market-price offer, however.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, March 28 (AP) -- German sports car maker Porsche AG said Wednesday it had completed its acquisition of more shares in Volkswagen AG, boosting its stake in Europe's biggest automaker to 30.94 percent and triggering a formal takeover offer to VW's shareholders. Porsche doesn't expect many VW shareholders will accept its below-market-price offer, however.

headline.main: Porsche Completes Purchase of More Volkswagen Shares

abstract: The consumer electronics retailer Circuit City Stores said on Wednesday it will explore a possible sale of its Canadian unit InterTan and replace 3,400 employees with lower-paid workers in a cost-cutting move, sending its shares up 2.5 percent.
lead_paragraph: The consumer electronics retailer Circuit City Stores said on Wednesday it will explore a possible sale of its Canadian unit InterTan and replace 3,400 employees with lower-paid workers in a cost-cutting move, sending its shares up 2.5 percent.

headline.main: In Circuit City Restructuring, Canadian Stores May Go

abstract: Citigroup has been down so long, it looks like up to John McDonald, an analyst at Banc of America Securities. Mr. McDonald on Wednesday raised his rating on Citigroup’s stock to “buy” from “neutral,” writing that “years of disappointing fundamental and stock price performance have set the bar low for Citi shares.” The upgrade follows reports that Citi is preparing for its first major overhaul since being formed from the merger of Travelers and Citicorp a decade ago. In his research note, Mr. McDonald said that “even modest improvement in management execution and financial results could be positive catalysts for the stock.”

In his research note, Mr. McDonald said that “even modest improvement in management execution and financial results could be positive catalysts for the stock.”

headline.main: Is Citi’s Long Slump Finally Over?

abstract: Ritchie Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm founded by a former college football star, A.R. Thane Ritchie, is close to a deal to sell about half of the assets in its main multistrategy fund to Reservoir Capital Group, according to news reports.

abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group have brought in a Texas-size posse of lobbyists in what seems to be an attempt to keep Washington from upsetting their proposed buyout of the energy giant TXU. abstract: Given Wall Street’s fascination with the proposed initial public offering of Blackstone Group, it was probably just a matter of time before someone set up a blog solely dedicated to the (potential) event. But the creator of “Inside the Blackstone I.P.O.” is not some hardcore private equity wonk — it is the Service Employees International Union, one of the biggest labor organizations in the United States. The anonymous blog’s connection with the union was disclosed Wednesday in an S.E.I.U. press release, in which Stephen Lerner, assistant to the president of the Service Employees International Union, questioned the benefits to society of a publicly traded Blackstone:

abstract: Cadbury Schweppes has candy on the brain. Prodded by activist investor Nelson Peltz, the British company said earlier this month it would split off its beverage unit to focus on becoming a giant in the confections business. The announcement had many analysts speculating that both pieces of the company could be attractive takeover targets. But Cadbury Schweppes chief executive Todd Stitzer hinted at a different outcome this week, suggesting it would make sense for Cadbury to buy United States-based Hershey, something it unsuccessfully tried to do in 2002.

snippet: Services like Pandora, Last.fm and Slacker evaluate your musical tastes, then serve up a continuous stream of programming to match.
lead_paragraph: FOR all the talk about satellite radio, the most vibrant frontier in radio may be the Web. Many traditional AM and FM stations have begun streaming on the Internet, along with hundreds of smaller online-only operators. Even subscription download services like Napster, Rhapsody and Urge from MTV have preprogrammed radio for users who are not in the mood to hunt for tracks.

lead_paragraph: Close readers of executive pay filings in recent years have noticed a tendency among companies to reward managers based on performance that is said to have exceeded their peers’. abstract: Delkin’s SensorScope is a modified five-times-power magnifying lens for checking sensors to see if they are dirty.

abstract: General Motors, which significantly improved its financial performance in 2006 but failed to earn a profit, said on Wednesday that for a second consecutive year, it would not pay cash bonuses to top executives. Mitchell’s management is also investing in the deal and will have a stake of about 15 percent.

abstract: Texas state regulators are demanding $210 million in fines from the energy company TXU for allegedly manipulating the wholesale power market in 2005. It would mark the largest penalty ever proposed by the Texas Public Utility Commission’s staff. TXU, which is currently the subject of a $45 billion buyout proposal, called the accusations “flatly wrong” and said it planned to contest the findings.

abstract: DealBook comes to you this morning from New Orleans, where Tulane University Law School’s 19th Annual Corporate Law Institute is just getting under way. Many of the nation’s most prominent deal lawyers, including Casey Cogut of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and Richard Katcher of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, are here to talk tactics and drink mint juleps. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Delaware’s Court of Chancery is here as well, and he is already talking about two of his favorite subjects: go shops and staple financing. We won’t dwell on the legal jargon, but we will bring you updates throughout the day and in tomorrow’s e-mail report.

abstract: The world’s hedge funds managed more than $2 trillion at the end of 2006, 30 percent more than a year earlier, even as returns trailed, according to a survey. More than 350 hedge fund managers look after more than $1 billion each, according to HedgeFund Intelligence’s first global review of the industry. Europe is the world’s fastest-growing hedge fund market, while most assets in the category are managed out of the United States, the London-based researcher said.

abstract: NEW YORK (Reuters) - CarMax Inc., the largest retailer of used cars in the United States, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, helped by strong sales and Internet traffic.

headline.main: Carmax Posts 15 Percent Rise in Earnings

abstract: Advanstar, a business-to-business marketer, will be acquired by a consortium led by a media-focused private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson, for $1.14 billion in cash. Veronis and its partners, Citigroup Private Equity and New York Life Capital Partners, will buy the company from its current sponsor, Credit Suisse‘s DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, which has already approved the deal.
lead_paragraph: Advanstar, a business-to-business marketer, will be acquired by a consortium led by a media-focused private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson, for $1.14 billion in cash. Veronis and its partners, Citigroup Private Equity and New York Life Capital Partners, will buy the company from its current sponsor, Credit Suisse‘s DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, which has already approved the deal.

headline.main: Veronis Suhler to Buy Advanstar

abstract: If hedge fund managers want to dispel their air of secrecy, this is probably not the way to do it. The folks at Solengo Capital, the firm being opened by former traders of the collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, have apparently told at least two blogs to remove Solengo’s marketing materials from their Web site, claiming they are not authorized to disseminate them. One of the blogs, Greg Newton’s Naked Shorts, agreed to take down the brochure, telling Reuters that although he did not think he was legally required to do so, “something like this can very quickly be a big legal bill.”
lead_paragraph: If hedge fund managers want to dispel their air of secrecy, this is probably not the way to do it. The folks at Solengo Capital, the firm being opened by former traders of the collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, have apparently told at least two blogs to remove Solengo’s marketing materials from their Web site, claiming they are not authorized to disseminate them. One of the blogs, Greg Newton’s Naked Shorts, agreed to take down the brochure, telling Reuters that although he did not think he was legally required to do so, “something like this can very quickly be a big legal bill.”

headline.main: As Pitch Leaks to Web, a Hedge Fund Wants Quiet

abstract: There are increasing complaints among shareholders that companies are selling out to private equity at bargain prices — leaving the buyout shops to enjoy the upside when the business gets sold or taken public again. But Robert Kindler, Morgan Stanley‘s vice chairman of investment banking, says these critics are generally off-base. In his opening speech Thursday to deal lawyers at Tulane Law School’s Corporate Law Institute, Mr. Kindler suggested that, in this torrid buyout market, most companies are getting top dollar when they agree to go private.
lead_paragraph: There are increasing complaints among shareholders that companies are selling out to private equity at bargain prices — leaving the buyout shops to enjoy the upside when the business gets sold or taken public again. But Robert Kindler, Morgan Stanley‘s vice chairman of investment banking, says these critics are generally off-base. In his opening speech Thursday to deal lawyers at Tulane Law School’s Corporate Law Institute, Mr. Kindler suggested that, in this torrid buyout market, most companies are getting top dollar when they agree to go private.

headline.main: Should Companies Sell While the Selling Is Good?

abstract: Thursday’s report that BCE, the owner of Bell Canada, might be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in Canada’s largest buyout drew this carefully worded statement from the company: There are “no ongoing discussions being held with any private equity investor with respect to any privatization of the company or any similar transaction.”
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s report that BCE, the owner of Bell Canada, might be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in Canada’s largest buyout drew this carefully worded statement from the company: There are “no ongoing discussions being held with any private equity investor with respect to any privatization of the company or any similar transaction.”

headline.main: Mixed Signals on BCE Buyout Rumor

abstract: Mechel, a Russian metals and mining company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said Thursday it would acquire Southern Kuzbass Power Plant for about $265 million. The deal follows an auction for the power station, which was split off from Kuzbassenergo, a Russian utility, as part of a 2006 restructuring. Mechel said that the acquisition was part of a strategy to reduce costs by generating some of its own power.
lead_paragraph: Mechel, a Russian metals and mining company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said Thursday it would acquire Southern Kuzbass Power Plant for about $265 million. The deal follows an auction for the power station, which was split off from Kuzbassenergo, a Russian utility, as part of a 2006 restructuring. Mechel said that the acquisition was part of a strategy to reduce costs by generating some of its own power.

headline.main: Russian Steelmaker Mechel Buys Power Plant

abstract: The big investment banks are everywhere these days, underwriting public offerings, advising buyers and providing deal financing — often on behalf of the same company. This ubiquity has created some concern when a bank needs to be found to handle a “go shop” provision in a takeover agreement, which essentially creates a window during which the target tries to drum up better offers. The dilemma: Does the desire for a completely independent bank trump the desire for a bank with sufficient resources and relevant experience?
lead_paragraph: The big investment banks are everywhere these days, underwriting public offerings, advising buyers and providing deal financing — often on behalf of the same company. This ubiquity has created some concern when a bank needs to be found to handle a “go shop” provision in a takeover agreement, which essentially creates a window during which the target tries to drum up better offers. The dilemma: Does the desire for a completely independent bank trump the desire for a bank with sufficient resources and relevant experience?

headline.main: Investment Banks’ Brave, New, Conflicted World

abstract: For those who complain that initial public offerings are having a tough time, Wednesday will have provided no solace. Three I.P.O.’s that opened that day raised about 21 percent less than they sought, potentially casting a shadow over three offerings set to debut this week. Bloomberg News notes that Super Micro Computer and SenoRx cut their prices to complete their deals, while GSI Technology lowered the number of shares offered. (The reasons why the companies’ offerings were less successful than expected isn’t clear. Bloomberg offers a slowing economy and declining stock prices as possible culprits.)
lead_paragraph: For those who complain that initial public offerings are having a tough time, Wednesday will have provided no solace. (The reasons why the companies’ offerings were less successful than expected isn’t clear. Bloomberg offers a slowing economy and declining stock prices as possible culprits.)

headline.main: A No Good, Very Bad Day for I.P.O.’s

abstract: Going private is a “long-term option” for McClatchy, according to Gary Pruitt, the newspaper chain’s chief executive. But first, he told a crowd at Syracuse University’s Newhouse School, he must put the company, which is the United States’ third-largest newspaper publisher, “in a position to have the flexibility to go private.”

abstract: Last year’s implosion at Amaranth Advisors was so huge it caused many people to conclude that the hedge-fund business was in meltdown mode. But a new study paints a different picture, finding that there were fewer hedge fund liquidations in 2006 than there were in 2005. (There were fewer fund launches as well.)
lead_paragraph: Last year’s implosion at Amaranth Advisors was so huge it caused many people to conclude that the hedge-fund business was in meltdown mode. headline.main: Some Reality Checks on Hedge Funds

abstract: Voestalpine, the biggest steel maker in Austria, agreed to buy a specialty-steel producer, Boehler-Uddeholm, for 3.52 billion euros ($4.69 billion), foiling a bid by a private equity company, CVC Capital Partners. Voestalpine, based in Linz, said it had agreed to pay 69 euros a share for Boehler. The acquisition will give Voestalpine a steel maker with customers worldwide including the Boeing Company and Airbus. CVC Capital, which is based in London, said last week that it planned to bid for Boehler, but Boehler, based in Vienna, said it opposed the bid.

abstract: Five generations of the family that owns and operates the McIlhenny Company have kept the Tabasco sauce business going while weathering many storms.
snippet: Five generations of the family that owns and operates the McIlhenny Company have kept the Tabasco sauce business going while weathering many storms.
lead_paragraph: AVERY ISLAND, La. ­ In April, board members and shareholders of the McIlhenny Company plan to gather here for their annual meeting. Unlike well-publicized events at big public companies this year, where activist shareholders often hope to create a stir, a private gathering is planned, and the agenda will probably not be debated. The meeting promises to be what it always is: one part business and one part family reunion.

headline.main: This Family’s Hot Stuff

abstract: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said Thursday that “evidence of misconduct” had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its board’s audit committee had “identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment.” The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.
lead_paragraph: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said Thursday that “evidence of misconduct” had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its board’s audit committee had “identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment.” The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.

headline.main: Dell Reports It Has Found ‘Misconduct’

abstract: Talk of an I.P.O. for Gianni Versace is in fashion as the company posted net profits of $24.1 million for last year on Thursday. Speaking to Women’s Wear Daily, chief executive Giancarlo DiRisio said that he is looking to get Versace on track for a possible stock market listing. But, he stressed it’s up to the owners to decide whether they want to take the company public. A decision will be made later this year.

abstract: With the influence of hedge funds over publicly traded companies back in the spotlight thanks to developments at Dutch financial services giant ABN Amro Bank, both hedge funds and private equity investors came under fire on several European fronts Thursday. Political leaders urged talks at the European Union level and Socialists in the European Parliament released a critical report on “secretive financial deals.”
lead_paragraph: With the influence of hedge funds over publicly traded companies back in the spotlight thanks to developments at Dutch financial services giant ABN Amro Bank, both hedge funds and private equity investors came under fire on several European fronts Thursday. Political leaders urged talks at the European Union level and Socialists in the European Parliament released a critical report on “secretive financial deals.”

headline.main: Europeans Lash Out at Hedge Funds, Private Equity Investors

abstract: Michael Dell’s MSD Capital and the Rockpoint Group have acquired the Kona Village Resort. The 82-acre Kona Village Resort in Hawaii has 125 bungalows on the beach next to 865-acre Hualalai Resort, a master-planned residential resort community that includes the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai which is owned by MSD Capital and Rockpoint Group as well. The resort dates back to 1965 and has been listed by Forbes magazine as one of the top 10 family luxury resorts in the country.
lead_paragraph: Michael Dell’s MSD Capital and the Rockpoint Group have acquired the Kona Village Resort. The 82-acre Kona Village Resort in Hawaii has 125 bungalows on the beach next to 865-acre Hualalai Resort, a master-planned residential resort community that includes the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai which is owned by MSD Capital and Rockpoint Group as well. The resort dates back to 1965 and has been listed by Forbes magazine as one of the top 10 family luxury resorts in the country.

headline.main: Dell Founder Says ‘Aloha’ to Kona Village

abstract: Texas state electricity regulators are considering a review of Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts’ $45 billion buyout offer for TXU. abstract: Amaranth Advisors was sued by the San Diego County retirement fund for securities fraud, a step the hedge fund said may delay refunds to clients hurt when it collapsed under $6.6 billion in losses in September. The fallen hedge fund lied about trading strategies and made “excessively risky and volatile investments,” according to a complaint filed yesterday by the San Diego County Employees Retirement Association. Amaranth said fighting the lawsuit, the first tied to the largest-ever hedge-fund failure, will drain remaining assets earmarked for investors.

abstract: A rift has arisen among larger technology companies and smaller venture capital firms over whether dramatic changes to U.S. patent law are necessary, CNet News.com reported Thursday.
